aberrant.abnormal: When the financial director started screaming and throwing food at his co-workers, the police had to come in to deal with his aberrant behavior.

aberration.deviation: Aberrations in climate have become the norm: rarely a week goes by without some meteorological phenomenon making headlines.

abjure.give up: While the church believed that Galileo abjured the heliocentric theory under the threat of torture, he later wrote a book clearly supporting his theory.

aboveboard.honest: The mayor, despite his avuncular face plastered about the city, was hardly aboveboard - some concluded that it was his ingratiating smile that allowed him to engage in corrupt behavior and get away with it.

abrogate.overturn a law: As part of the agreement between the labor union and the company, the workers abrogated their right to strike for four years in exchange for better health insurance.

abstain.hold back from doing: Considered a health nut, Jessica abstained from anything containing sugar - even chocolate.

abstruse.incomprehensible: Physics textbooks ca seem abstruse to the uninitiated that readers feel as though they are looking at hieroglyphics.

abysmal.really horrible: Coach Ramsay took his newest player off the field after watching a painful few minutes of her abysmal performance.

accolade.high praise: Jean Paul-Sartre was not a fan of accolades, and as such, he refused to accept the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1964.

acerbic.harsh: Most movie critics are acerbic towards summer blockbusters, often referring to them as garbage.

acme.highest point: The new Cessna airplanes will be the acme of comfort, offering reclining seats and ample legroom.

acrimony.bitterness: The acrimonious dispute between the president and vice-president sent a clear signal to voters: the health of the current administration was imperiled.

adamant.unyielding: Civil rights icon Rosa Parks will forever be remembered for adamantly refusing to give up her seat on a public bus - even after the bus driver insisted, she remained rooted in place.

adjudicate.judge: Only those with the most refined palates were able to adjudicate during the barbeque competition.

admonish.warn: Before the concert began, security personnel admonished the crowd not to come up on stage during the performance.

admonitory.serving to warn: At the assembly, the high school vice-principal gave the students an admonitory speech, warning them of the many risks and dangers of prom night.

advocate.support a cause: While Senator Radge privately approved of gay marriage, he was unwilling to advocate for the cause in public.

aesthete.appreciator of beauty: A true aesthete, Marty would spend hours at the Guggenheim Museum, staring at the same Picasso.

aesthetic.relating to beauty: The director, not known for his aesthetic sensibilities, decided not to use costumes at all, and put on the play in everyday clothing.

affable.likeable: For all his surface affability, Marco was remarkably glum when he wasn't around other people.

affluent.wealthy: The center of the city had sadly become a pit of penury, while, only five miles away, multi-million dollar homes spoke of affluence.

afford.give opportunity for: The summit of Mt. Kilimanjaro affords a panoramic view that encompasses both Tanzania and Kenya.

alacrity.eager willingness: The first three weeks in his new job, Mark worked with such alacrity that upper management knew it would be giving him a promotion.

altruism.concern for others: Albert Schweitzer spent most of his life doing missionary work as a doctor in Africa, seeking no reward, apparently motivated only by altruism.

amalgam.mixture: The band's music was an amalgam of hip-hop, flamenco and jazz, blending the three styles with surprising results.

ambiguous.having multiple meanings: The coach told his team, 'Move towards that side of the field': because he did not point, his directions were ambiguous, and the team had no idea to which side he was referring.

ambivalent.having mixed emotions: Sam was ambivalent about studying for the exam because doing so ate up a lot of his time, yet he was able to improve his analytical skills.

ameliorate.improve: Three Cups of Tea tells the story of western man who hopes to ameliorate poverty and the lack of education in Afghanistan.

amenable.cooperative: Even though she did not like the outdoors, Shirley was generally amenable and so her brother was able to persuade her to go camping.

amiable.friendly: Amy's name was very apt: she was so  amiable that she was twice voted class president.

amok.frenzied: Wherever the bowl haircut teen-idol went, his legions of screaming fans ran through the streets amok, hoping for a glance at his boyish face.

amorphous.shapeless: His study plan for the GRE was at best amorphous; he would do questions from random pages in any one of the seven test prep books.

amply.fully: The boat was amply supplied for its year at sea - no man would go hungry or thirsty.

anachronism.belonging to another time: Dressed in 15th century clothing each day, Edward was a walking anachronism.

analogous.similar: In many ways, the Internet's transformative effect on society has been analogous to that of the printing press.

anathema.detested person: Hundreds of years ago, Galileo was anathema to the church; today the church is anathema to some on the left side of the political spectrum.

anemic.lacking energy: After three straight shows ,the lead actress gave an anemic performance the fourth night, barely speaking loudly enough for those in the back rows to hear.

animosity.extreme hostility: The governor's animosity toward his rival was only inflamed when the latter spread false lies regarding the governor's first term.

anodyne.that which soothes: Muzak, which is played in department stores, is intended to be an anodyne, but is often so cheesy and over-the-top that customers become irritated.

anomalous.not normal: According to those who do not believe in climate change, the extreme weather over the last five years is simply anomalous - daily temperature should return to their old averages, they believe.

anomaly.oddity: After Sally found an anomaly in the data, she had to redo the entire experiment.

antedate.precede: Harry was so unknowledgable that he was unaware that Egyptian pharaohs antedated the American revolution.

antic.grotesque: The clown's antic act was too extreme for the youngest children, who left the room in tears.

antipathy.hatred: Maria had an antipathy for tour groups, often bolting to the other side of the museum as soon as she saw a chaperone leading a group of wide-eyed tourists.

antiquated.old: Aunt Betty had antiquated notions about marriage, believing that a man should court a woman for at least a year before receiving a kiss.

antithetical.sharply contrasted: His deep emotional involvement with these ideas is, in fact, antithetical to the detachment Buddhism practices.

apathetic.uncaring: Mr. Thompson was so talented at teaching math that even normally apathetic students took interest.

apathy.absence of emotion: Widespread apathy among voters led to a very small turnout on election day.

apex.summit: The Ivy League is considered the apex of the secondary education system.

aphorism.short saying: Nietzsche was known for using aphorisms, sometimes encapsulating a complex philosophical thought in a mere sentence.

aphoristic.concise, true: Sometimes I can't stand Nathan because he tries to impress everyone by being aphoristic, but he just states the obvious.

aplomb.coolness under strain: Nancy acted with aplomb during dangerous situations - she once calmly climbed up an oak tree to save a cat.

apocryphal.questionably fake: The web is notorious for sandwiching apocryphal stories between actual news.

apogee.highest point: The apogee of the Viennese style of music, Mozart's music continues to mesmerize audiences well into the 21st century.

apostate.rejector of faith: An apostate of the Republican Party, Sheldon has yet to become affiliated with any party and dubs himself independent.

apothegm.short saying: Winston Churchill is famous for many apothegms, but this might be his most famous: It has been said that democracy is the worst form of government except all the others that have been tried.

apotheosis.height of development: As difficult as it is to imagine, the apotheosis of Mark Zuckerberg's career, many believe, is yet to come.

appease.make less angry: Neville Chamberlain, the British prime minister during WWII, tried to appease Hitler and in doing so sent a clear message: you can walk all over us.

apposite.appropriate: For a writer with such quick wit, Jonathan Swift has a rather apposite name.

appreciable.noticeable: There is an appreciable difference between those who say they can get the job done and those who actually get the job done.

apprehension.anxiety: Test day can be one of pure apprehension, as many students worry about their test scores.

approbatory.showing approval: Although it might not be her best work, Hunter's new novel has received generally approbatory reviews.

appropriate.take forcefully: The government appropriated land that was occupied by squatters, sending them scurrying for another place to live.

appurtenant.supporting: In hiking Mt. Everest, Sherpas are appurtenant, helping climbers both carry gear and navigate treacherous paths.

arbitrary.random: One of the arbitrary decrees in place during the emperor's rule is that all citizens pay him weekly homage at his place.

arcane.understood by few: Most college fraternities are known for arcane rituals that those hoping to join the fraternity must learn.

arch.teasing: The baroness was arch, making playful asides on the townspeople; yet because they couldn't pick up on her dry humor, they thought her supercilious.

archaic.very old: Hoping to sound intelligent, Mary spoke in archaic English that was right out of Jane Austen's Pride and Prejudice - needless to say, she didn't have many friends.

arduous.requiring great effort: In order to deal with the arduous cross-country journey, truck drivers often survive on a string of caffeinated drinks, staying awake for up to 30 hours at a time.

argument.increase: Ideally, the restaurant's augmented menu will expand its clientele and increase its profits.

arrant.utter: An arrant fool, Lawrence surprised nobody when he lost all his money in a pyramid scheme that was every bit as transparent as it was corrupt.

arriviste.upstart: The city center was aflutter with arrivistes who each tried to outdo one another with their ostentatious sports cars and chic evening dress.

arrogate.seize without authority: Arriving at the small town, the outlaw arrogated the privileges of a lord, asking the frightened citizens to provide food, drink and entertainment.

artful.clever and deceptive: Berni Madoff's artful Ponzi scheme stole billions of dollars from investors and is considered the largest financial fraud in US history.

artifice.trickery: The mayoral candidates both spent much of the campaign accusing each other of artifices designed to mislead the voting public.

artless.without deception: Despite the president's seemingly artless speeches, he was a skilled and ruthless negotiator.

artlessness.innocence: I, personally, found the artlessness of her speech charming.

ascendancy.dominant position: The ascendancy of the Carlsbad water polo team is clear - they have a decade of championships behind them.

ascetic.practicing self-denial: His ascetic life is the main reason he inspired so many followers, especially since he gave up wealth and power to live in poverty.

ascribe.attribute: History ascribes The Odyssey and The Ilead to Homer, but scholars now debate whether he was a historical figure or a fictitious name.

askance.suspiciously: The old couple looked askance at the teenagers seated next to them, whispering to each other, 'They've got rings through their noses and purple hair!'.

asperity.harshness of manner: The editor was known for his asperity, often sending severe letters of rejection to amateur writers.

assail.attack: In the weekly paper, the editor assailed the governor for wasting hundreds of thousands of dollars in public projects that quickly failed.

assiduously.with great care: The top college football program recruits new talent assiduously, only choosing those who were the top in their county.

assuage.make less severe: Her fear that the new college would be filled with unknown faces was assuaged when she recognized her childhood friend standing in the line.

atavism.throwback: Much of the modern art movement was an atavism to a style of art found only in small villages through Africa and South America.

attenuate.taper off: Her animosity toward Bob attenuated over the years, and she even went so far as to invite him to her party.

audacious.taking bold risks: As all of the other campers cowered in tents, Bill, armed only with a flashlight, audaciously tracked down the bear that had raided their food.

audacity.boldness: She surprised her colleagues by having the audacity to publicly criticize the findings of a distinguished scientist.

auspicious.favorable: Despite an auspicious beginning, Mike's road trip became a series of mishaps, and he was soon stranded and penniless, leaning against his wrecked automobile.

austere.unadorned: His lifestyle of revelry and luxurious excess could hardly be called austere.

autocratic.tyrannical: The last true autocratic country is certainly NOrth Korea; there's no other country with a leader who exercises as much control over all aspects of life as much as Kim Jong-un does.

autonomous.independent: Many of the factory workers are worried about being replaced by machines and computers that will work completely autonomously.

avarice.greed: The Spanish conquistadors were known for their avarice, plundering Incan land and stealing Incan gold.

avaricious.greedy: Since avaricious desire is similar to gluttony or lust - sins of excess - it was listed as one of the seven deadly sins by the Catholic church.

avert.prevent: The struggling video game company put all of its finances into one final, desperate project to avert bankruptcy.

avid.enthusiastic, keen: Martin is an avid birdwatcher, often taking long hikes into remote mountains to see some rare eagle.

badger.pester: Badgered by his parents to find a job, the 30-year-old loafer instead joined a gang of itinerant musicians.

baleful.threatening: Movies often use storms or rain clouds as a baleful omen of evil events that will soon befall the main character.

balk.refuse to accept: The students were willing to clean up the broken glass, but when the teacher asked them to mop the entire floor, they balked, citing reasons why they needed to leave.

banal.over-familiar: The professor used such banal expressions that many students in the class either fell asleep from boredom or stayed awake to complete his sentences so as to humor their fellow classmates.

banality.cliche: Herbert regarded the minister's remark as a mere banality until Sharon pointed out profound implications to the seemingly obvious words.

banish.get rid of: The most difficult part of the fast was banishing thoughts of food.

base.without principles: She was not so base as to begrudge the beggar the unwanted crumbs from her dinner plate.

bastardization.corruption: The movie World War Z is a complete bastardization of the book with little more in common than zombies and a title.

beatific.blissfully happy: Often we imagine all monks to wear the beatific smile of the Buddha, but, like any of us, a monk can have a bad day and not look very happy.

becoming.suitable: Her dress was becoming and made her look even more beautiful.

begrudge.envy: Sitting all alone in his room, Harvey begrudged the happiness of the other children playing outside his window.

behoove.be one's duty: The teacher looked down at the student and said, it would behoove you to be in class on time and complete your homework, so that you don't repeat freshman English for a third straight year.

belie.misrepresent: The smile on her face belies the pain she must feel after the death of her husband.

belittle.put somebody down: A good teacher will never belittle his students, but will instead empower them.

bellicose.warlike: Known for their bellicose ways, the Spartans were once the most feared people from Peloponnesus to Persia.

belligerent.eager to fight: Tom said he was arguing the matter for purely philosophical reasons, but his belligerent tone indicated an underlying anger about the issue.

bemoan.lament: While the CFO carefully explained all the reasons for the cuts in benefits, after the meeting employees bemoaned the cuts as further evidence that management was against them.

benighted.ignorant: Far from being a period of utter benightedness, the Medieval Ages produced some great works of theological speculation.

benign.harmless: I remember my grandfather's face was wrinkled, benign, and calm.

bereft.sad because of loss: After 64 years of marriage, Williams was bereft after the death of his wife.

besiege.harass: After discovering a priceless artifact in her backyard, Jane was besieged by phone calls, emails, and reporters all trying to buy, hold or see the rare piece of history.

besmirch.dishonor: The prince's distasteful choice of words besmirched no only his own name, but the reputation of the entire royal family.

besotted.very infatuated: Even though her father did not approve, Juliet became besotted with the young Romeo.

betray.reveal: With the gold medal at stake, the gymnast awaited his turn, his quivering lip betraying his intense emotions.

bilious.grumpy: Rex was bilious all morning, and his face would only take on a look of contentedness when he'd had his morning cup of coffee.

bleak.hopeless: Unremitting overcast skies tend to lead people to create bleak literature and lugubrious music - compare England's band Radiohead to any band from Southern California.

blinkered.limited in outlook: In gambling, the addict is easily blinkered by past successes and/or past failures, forgetting that the outcome of any one game is independent of the games that preceded it.

bolster.support: The case for the suspect's innocence was bolstered considerably by the fact that neither fingerprints nor DNA were found at the scene.

boon.helpful thing: Modern technology has been a boon to the travel industry.

boorish.ill mannered: Bookowski was known for being a boorish drunk and alienating close friends and family.

bowdlerize.censor: To receive an R rating, the entire movie was bowdlerized because it contained so much violence and grotesque subject matter.

brazen.without shame: Their large donations to the local police department gave the drug cartel the brazen confidence to do their business out in the open.

bridle.restrain: New curfew laws have bridled people's tendency to go out at night.

bristle.react angrily: As we discussed the painting, I noticed the artist's wife bristling at our criticism, ready to defend her husband's work.

broadside.verbal attack: Political broadsides are usually strongest in the weeks leading up to a national election.

bromide.unoriginal remark: Instead of sharing his umbrella ,the cheeky stranger offered Martha the following bromide: Looks like it's raining.

brook.put up with: While she was at the chalkboard, the teacher did not brook any form of talking - even a tiny peep resulted in afternoon detention.

browbeat.boss around, bully: During the interrogation, the suspect was browbeaten into signing a false confession.

brusquely.bluntly: Not one for social pleasantries, the Chief of Staff would brusquely ask his subordinates what he wanted, even coffee.

buck.resist: The profits at our firm bucked the general downturn that affected the real estate industry.

bucolic.rural: The noble families of England once owned vast expanses of beautiful, bucolic land.

bumbling.clumsy: Within a week of starting, the bumbling new waiter was unceremoniously fired.

burgeon.grow rapidly: China's housing market is burgeoning, but some predict that the growth is merely a bubble and will burst much like the US real estate bubble of 2008.

buttress.support: China's economy has been buttressed by a global demand for the electronic parts the country manufactures.

byzantine.overly complex: Getting a driver's license is not simply a matter of taking a test; the regulations and procedures are so byzantine that many have found themselves at the mercy of the Department of Motor Vehicles.

cadaverous.corpse-like: Some actors take challenging roles in which they have to lose so much weight that they appear cadaverous.

callow.inexperienced: Both Los Angeles and New York are known for callow out-of-towners hoping to make it big.

calumny.slander: With the presidential primaries well under way, the air is thick with calumny, and the mud already waist-high.

canard.false report: The public will always be fooled by the media's canards.

candid.honest and straightforward: Although I was unhappy that the relationship ended, I appreciated Frank's candidness about why he was ready to move on from the relationship.
candid.straightforward: Even with a perfect stranger, Charles was always candid and would rarely hold anything back.

capitulate.surrender: Paul, losing 19-0 in a ping-pong match against his nimble friend, basically capitulated when he played the last two points with his eyes closed.

capricious.impulsive: Nearly every month our capricious CEO had a new plan to turn the company around, and none of them worked because we never gave them the time they needed to succeed.

cardinal.most important: Most cultures consider gambling a cardinal sin and thus have outlawed its practice.

carping.fault-finding: What seemed like incessant nagging and carping about my behavior from my mother turned out to be wise and useful advice that has served me well.

castigate.scold harshly: Drill sergeants are known to castigate new recruits so mercilessly that the latter often break down during their first week of training.

cataclysm.violent upheaval: The introduction of smallpox was a cataclysm for Native Americans, killing off more than half of their population.

catalyst.cause of a process: Rosa Park's refusal to give up her bus seat acted as a catalyst for the Civil Rights Movement, setting into motion historic changes for African-Americans.

catholic.universal: Jonah's friends said that Jonah's taste in music was eclectic; Jonah was quick to point out that not only was his taste eclectic but it was also catholic: he enjoyed music from countries as far-flung as Mali and Mongolia.

cavalier.not caring: Percy dismissed the issue with a cavalier wave of his hand.

cede.give up control: Eventually, all parents must cede control of their growing children's educations and allow their offspring some autonomy.

celerity.quickness: We aim to respond to customers' questions with celerity and accuracy, with no longer than a 24 hour wait time.

censor.remove objectionable material: Every fall, high school English teachers are inundated by requests to censor their curriculum by removing The Catcher in the Rye and Scarlet Letter from their reading lists.

censure.express disapproval: After being caught in bed with a mistress, the mayor was quickly censured by the city council.

cerebral.brainy: A cerebral analysis of most pop music finds it to be simple and childish, but that ignores the point - the music's effect on the listener.

chagrin.dismay: Much to the timid writer's chagrin, the audience chanted his name until he came back on the stage.

champion.speak in favor of: Martin Luther King Jr. championed civil rights fiercely throughout his short life.

charlatan.con artist: Ray Kurzweil is no charlatan. He writes about immortality because he truly believes in it - not just to sell expensive magazines.

chary.cautious: Having received three speeding tickets in the last two months, Jack was chary of driving at all above the speed limit, even on a straight stretch of highway that looked empty for miles ahead.

chastise.scold: Though chastised for eating the snacks for the party, Lawrence shrugged off his mother's harsh words, and continued to plow through jars of cookies and boxes of donuts.

chauvinism.feeling of superiority: Vegetarians argue that man is chauvinistic in his belief that animals do not consciously feel the pain we humans do.

chauvinist.elitist: The chauvinist lives on both sides of the political spectrum, outright shunning anybody whose ideas are not consistent with his own.

check.hold back from doing: Deserted for six months, the property began to look more like a jungle and less like a residence with no one around to check the growth of weeds in the front yard.

checkered.disreputable: One by one, the presidential candidates dropped out of the race, their respective checkered pasts - from embezzlements to infidelity - sabotaging their campaigns.

chimera.illusion: Many believe that a world free of war is a chimera - a dream that ignores humanity's violent tendencies.

chivalrous.courteous: Marco's chivalrous ways, like opening doors and pulling out chairs, was much appreciated by his date.

choleric.easily angered: While a brilliant lecturer, Mr. Dawson came across as choleric and unapproachable - very rarely did students come to his office.

chortle.laugh merrily: Walking into the cafe, I could hear happy, chortling people and smell the rich aroma of roasted coffee beans.

churlish.ill-mannered: The manager was unnecessarily churlish to his subordinates, rarely deigning to say hello, but always quick with a sartorial jab if someone happened to be wearing anything even slightly mismatching.

circumscribe.restrict within limits: Their tour of South America was circumscribed so that they saw only popular destinations and avoided the dangerous parts of the cities.

circumvent.get out of duty: One way of circumventing the GRE is to apply to a grad school that does not require GRE scores.

clemency.mercy: In the final moments of the trial, during his closing speech, Philip was nearly begging the judge for clemency.

coalesce.fuse: Over time, the various tribes coalesced into a single common culture with one universal language.

cogent.convincing: A cogent argument will change the minds of even the most skeptical audience.

cohesive.united: A well-written, cohesive essay will keep on topic at all times, never losing sight of the main argument.

collusion.secret cooperation: Many have argued that Lee Harry Oswald, JFK's assassin, was in collusion with other criminals; others maintained that Oswald was a lone gunman.

colossal.humongous: Few appreciate the colossal scale of the sun: if hollow, it could contain a million earths.

commendable.worthy of praise: The efforts of the firefighters running into the burning building were commendable.

commensurate.in proportion to: The convicted felon's life sentence was commensurate with the heinousness of his crime.

complacent.contented to a fault: After the water polo team won their sixth championship, they became complacent and didn't even make it to the playoffs the next year.

complaisant.cheerfully obedient: On her first day at the job, Annie was complaisant, fulfilling every request of her new employer and anticipating future requests.

complementary.matching: The head waiter was careful to tell the amateur diners that red wine was complementary with beef, each bringing out subtle taste notes in the other.

complicit.taking part in: While the grand jury cleared the Senator of all criminal charges, in the public mind he was still complicit in the corruption.

compound.make more intense: Her headache was compounded by the construction crew outside, which had six jackhammers going at the same time.

conciliate.make peace with: His opponents believed his gestures to be conciliatory, yet as soon as they put down their weapons, he unsheathed a hidden sword.

concomitant.accompanying: Concomitant with his desire for nature was a desire for the culture and energy of a big city.

conducive.helpful: Studying in a quiet room is conducive to learning; studying in a noisy environment makes learning more difficult.

conflagration.large fire: In the summer months, conflagrations are not uncommon in the southwest, due to the heat and lack of rain.

conflate.mix together: In her recent book, the author conflates several genres - the detective story, the teen thriller, and the vampire romance - to create a memorable read.

confound.utterly confuse: Though Harry loved numbers, he found calculus confounding.

conniving.conspiring to do bad: The queen was so conniving that, with the help of the prince, she tried to overthrow the king.

consecrate.make holy: At the church of Notre Dame in France, the new High Altar was consecrated in 1182.

conspicuous.obvious: American basketball players are always conspicuous when they go abroad - not only are they American, but some are over seven feet tall.

constraint.limit: We don't have many resources, so we'll have to work with some very tight constraints.

construe.interpret: The author's inability to take a side on the issue was construed by both his opponents and supporters as a sign of weakness.

consummate.masterful: Tyler was the consummate musician: he was able to play the guitar, harmonica, and the drum at the same time.

contemptuous.scornful: Always on the forefront of fashion, Vanessa looked contemptuously at anyone wearing dated clothing.

contentious.causing arguments: Since old grandpa Harry became very contentious during the summer when only reruns were on the TV, the grandkids learned to hide from him at every opportunity.

contingent.small group: A small contingent of those loyal to the king have gathered around the castle to defend it.

contrite.remorseful: Though he stole his little sister's licorice stick with malevolent glee, Chucky soon became contrite when his sister wouldn't stop crying.

contrition.remorse: Those who show contrition during their prison terms - especially when under review by a parole board - often get shortened sentences.

contrive.pull of a scheme: Despite a low GPA, he contrived to get into college, going so far as to write his own glowing letters of recommendation.

conundrum.difficult problem: Computers have helped solve some of the mathematical conundrums which have puzzled man for many centuries.

convivial.friendly and lively: The wedding reception was convivial; friends who hadn't seen each other for ages drank and ate together before heading to the dance floor.

convoluted.extremely complex: Instead of solving the math problem in three simple steps, Kumar used a convoluted solution requiring fifteen steps.

copious.abundant: In midsummer, there are copious popsicle stands at the beach; in the winter, there are none.

cornucopia.abundant supply: The International Food Expo was a cornucopia of culinary delights: gourmet foods from every continent were under one roof.

corollary.consequence: A corollary of Hurricane Sandy, which ravaged the east coast of the US, is a push to build higher sea walls to protect against future hurricanes.

corroborate.confirm: Her claim that frog populations were falling precipitously in Central America was corroborated by locals, who reported that many species of frogs had seemingly vanished overnight.

cosmopolitan.sophisticated and global: There are few cities in the world as diverse and cosmopolitan as New York.

cosseted.overly pampered: The kind and queen cosseted the young prince, giving him a prized miniature pony for his fifth birthday.

coterminous.equal in scope: The border of the state is coterminous with geographic limits on travel; the east and north are surrounded by a nearly uncrossable river and the south by a desert.

countermand.reverse a command: By the time the colonel countermanded his soldiers not to land in enemy territory, a few helicopters had already touched down amid heavy gunfire.

cow.intimidate: Do not be cowed by  a 3000-word vocabulary list: turn that list into a deck of flashcards.

craven.cowardly: Though the man could have at least alerted the police, he crouched cravenly in the corner as the old woman was mugged.

credence.belief: He placed no credence in physics, claiming that they offered no special powers beyond the ability to make people part with their money.

creditable.good nut not great: Critics agreed the movie was creditable, but few gave it more than three out of five stars.

credulity.tendency to believe: Virginia's wide eyed credulity as a five year old was replaced by suspicion after she learned that Santa Claus didn't really exist.

crestfallen.disappointed: I asked Maria on a date and she refused without a moment's thought; I was crestfallen.

cryptic.mysterious: Since Sarah did not want her husband to guess the Christmas present she had bought him, she only answered cryptically when he would ask her questions about it.

crystallize.become definite: Only after fifteen minutes of brainstorming did Samantha's ideas for the essay crystallize.

culminate.reach high point: Beethoven's musical genius culminated in the 9th Symphony, which many consider his greatest work.

culpability.state of guilt: Since John had left his banana peel at the top of the stairwell, he accepted culpability for Martha's broken leg.

cumbersome.difficult to carry: Only ten years ago, being an avid reader and a traveler meant carrying a cumbersome backpack stuffed with books - these days we only need an e-reader.

cupidity.greed for money: Some believe that people amassing as much wealth as possible is the meaning to life - yet they often realize that cupidity brings anything but happiness.

curmudgeon.grouch: Since Uncle Mike was the family curmudgeon, each Thanksgiving he was plied with copious amounts of wine, in the hope that he would become less grouchy.

dearth.shortage: I am surprised by the dearth of fast food chains; this is America and I assumed they were on every street.

debase.reduce the value: The third-rate script so debased the film that not even the flawless acting could save it from being a flop.

debonair.sophisticated, charming: James Bond is known for his good looks, high tech gadgets and debonair manner.

debunk.prove to be false: Richard Dawkins tries to debunk religious belief, but his ridicule tends to push people away from his points rather than convince them.

decimation.complete destruction: The decimation after atomic bombs were dropped on Hiroshima and Nagasaki is incomprehensible.

decorous.well-behaved: Sally's parties are decorous affairs, and instead of the usual beer and music, there is tea and intellectual conversation.

decorum.proper conduct: You will obey the rules of decorum for this courtroom or spend the night in a jail cell, said the judge to the prosecutor.

decry.speak out against: The entire audience erupted in shouts and curses, decrying the penalty card issued by the referee.

deferential.respectful: If you ever have the chance to meet the president, stand up straight and be deferential.

defray.pay cost of: In order for Sean to attend the prestigious college, his generous uncle helped defray the excessive tuition with a monthly donation.

degrade.humiliate: Jesse mockingly listed all of Nancy's faults in front of their friends, publicly degrading the poor girl.

deign.stoop to: The master of the house never deigned to answer questions from the servants.

delegate.assign: Since the senior manager had to go on many international business trips, she was forced to delegate many of her responsibilities to two lower-level managers.

deleterious.harmful: The BP oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico was deleterious to the fishing industry in the southern states.

deliberate.consider carefully: Emergency situations such as this call for immediate action and leave no room to deliberate over options.

delineate.describe in detail: After a brief summary of proper swimming technique, the coach delineated the specifics of each stoke, spending 30 minutes alone on the backstroke.

demean.insult: At first the soccer players bantered back and forth, but as soon as one of the players became demeaning, calling the other's mother a water buffalo, the ref whipped out a red card.

demur.object: Wallace disliked the cold, so he demurred when his friends suggested they go skiing in the Alps.

demure.modest, shy: The portrait of her in simple white blouse was sweet and demure.

denigrate.attack a reputation: Count Rumford denigrated the new theory of heat, demonstrating that it was wholly inadequate to explain the observations.

denote.be a sign of: Even if the text is not visible, the red octagon denotes stop to all motorists in America.

denouement.resolution of a story: At the denouement of the movie, all questions were answered, and the true identity of the robber was revealed.

derelict.avoiding duties: The teacher was derelict in her duties because she hadn't graded a single student paper in three weeks.

deride.put down: The nun derided the students for trying to sneak insects and worms into the classroom.

derisive.full of ridicule: I was surprised by her derisive tone; usually, she is sweet, soft spoken, and congenial.

derivative.unoriginal: Because the movies were utterly derivative of other popular movies, they did well at the box office.

derive.originate in: Many words in the English language are derived from Latin, including the word derive.

derogative.insulting: Never before have we seen a debate between two political candidates that was so derogative and filthy.

desecrate.ruin something holy: After desecrating the pharaoh's tomb, the archaeologist soon fell victim to a horrible illness.

desiccated.lacking vitality: Few novelists over 80 are able to produce anything more than desiccated works - boring shadows of former books.

desideratum.necessity: The desideratum of the environmental group is that motorists should rely on carpooling.

despot.tyrant: The Emperor Claudius was regarded as a fair-minded leader; his successor, Nero, was an absolute despot.

destitute.poor: Jean Valjean, is at first destitute, but through the grace of a priest, he makes something of his life.

detrimental.causing harm: Many know that smoking is detrimental to health, but processed sugar in large quantities is equally bad.

devolve.delegate: The company was full of managers known for devolving tasks to lower management, but never doing much work themselves.

diabolical.wicked: The conspirators, willing to dispatch anyone who stood in their way, hatched a diabolical plan to take over the city.

diatribe.bitter verbal attack: Steve's mom launched into a diatribe during the PTA meeting, contending that the school was little more than a daycare in which students stare at the wall and teachers stare at the chalkboard.

dictatorial.extremely bossy: The coach was dictatorial in his approach: no players could ever argue or question his approach.

didactic.instructive: Tolstoy's 'The Death of Ivan Illyich' is a didactic novel, instructing the reader on how to live a good life.

differentiate.identify differences between: Mozart's long melodies differentiate his compositions from the work of other late 18th century composers.

diffident.shy: As a young girl she was diffident and reserved, but now as an adult, she is confident and assertive.

dilapidated.run down: The main house has been restored but the gazebo is still dilapidated and unusable.

dilatory.time-wasting: Lawyers use dilatory tactics so that it takes years before the case is actually decided.

dilettante.dabbler: Fred has no formal medical training; while he likes to claim authority on medical issues, he is little more than a dilettante.

diligent.careful and hard-working: Michael was a diligent gardener, never leaving a leaf on the ground and regularly watering each plant.

diminutive.small: He prefers to be called a diminutive of his name: Bill instead of John William.

disabuse.lead one from error: As a child, I was quickly disabused of the notion that Santa Claus was a rotund benefactor of infinite largess - one night I saw my mother diligently wrapping presents and storing them under our Christmas tree.

disaffected.discontent: After watching his superior take rations from the soldiers, he quickly became disaffected and rebelled.

discord.disagreement: Despite all their talented players, the team was filled with discord - some players refused to talk to others - and lost most of their games.

discreet.careful: The professor thought that he was discreet, subtly wiping the stain off of his shirt, but as soon as he stepped off the podium a member of the audience pointed out a large ketchup stain.

discrete.separate: What was once known as Czechoslovakia has since split into two discrete, independent nations.

discriminate.differentiate: Sarah couldn't discriminate between a good wine and a bad wine, so she avoided wine tastings.

discursive.tangential: Many readers find it tough to read Moby Dick since the author is discursive, often cutting the action short to spend 20 pages on the history of a whale.

disenfranchise.deprive of votes: The U.S. constitution disenfranchised women until 1920 when they were given the right to vote.

disheartened.losing confidence: After the visiting team scored nine times, the home team's fans were disheartened, some leaving the game early.

disingenuous.pretending to be honest: Many adults think that they can lie to children, but kids are smart and know when people are disingenuous.

disinterested.unbiased: The potential juror knew the defendant, and therefore could not serve on the jury, which must consist only of disinterested members.

disparate.fundamentally different: With the advent of machines capable of looking inside the brain, fields as disparate as religion and biology have been brought together by scientists trying to understand what happens in the brain when people have a religious experience.

dispassionate.objective: A good scientist should be dispassionate, focusing purely on what the evidence says, without personal attachment.

dispatch.speed, efficiency: She finished her thesis with dispatch, amazing her advisors who couldn't believe she had written 60 scholarly pages so quickly.

dispensation.exemption: Since her father is a billionaire, she is given dispensation from many of the school's policies.

dissemble.act deceitfully: To get close to the senator, the assassin dissembled his intentions, convincing many people that he was a reporter for a well-known newspaper.

disseminate.spread: Before the effects of anesthesia were disseminated, patients had to experience the full pain of a surgery.

dissipate.squander: The recent graduates dissipated their earnings on trips to Las Vegas and cruises in Mexico.

dissolution.debauchery: Many Roman emperors were known for their dissolution, indulging in unspeakable desires of the flesh.

docile.easily managed: Barnyard animals are considerably more docile than the wild animals.

dog.pursue: Throughout his life, he was dogged by insecurities that inhibited personal growth.

dogmatic.opinionated: Bryan is dogmatic in his belief that the earth is flat, claiming that all pictures of a spherical earth are computer generated.

doleful.very sad: No event is more doleful than the passing of my mother, she was a shining star in my life, and it brings me great sadness to think that she is now gone.

dolorous.sorrowful: Chopin's ballads are filled with sharp changes in moods - a dolorous melody can give way to a lighthearted tempo.

doughty.brave, bold: I enjoy films in which a doughty group comes together to battle a force of evil.

dovetail.fit together tightly: Although Darwin's evolution and Mendel's genetics were developed in isolation from one another, they dovetail very well.

dupe.swindle: Once again a get-rich-fast internet scheme had duped Harold into submitting a 5000 dollar check to a sham operation.

duplicity.deceit: A life of espionage is one of duplicity: an agent must pretend to be someone totally different from who she or he actually is.

duress.compulsory force: The witness said he signed the contract under duress and argued that the court should cancel the agreement.

ebullient.enthusiastic: Can you blame him for his ebullient mood? He just graduated from medical school.

eccentric.peculiar: Mozart was well-known for his eccentricities, often speaking words backward to confuse those around him.

eclectic.having a variety: Joey was known for his eclectic tastes in music, one moment dancing to disco the next air conducting along to Beethoven's ninth symphony.

economical.avoiding waste: Journalists favor an economical style of writing, in which no unnecessary words are used and every sentence is as short as possible.

edifying.enlightening: I recently read an article in the Times about whether good literature is edifying or not; specifically, does reading more make a person more moral.

effervescent.bubbly: After the sales result, the manager was in a effervescent mood, letting several employees leave work earlier that day.

efficacious.effective: Since Maggie's cough syrup, which had expired five years back, was no longer efficacious, she coughed throughout the night.

effrontery.cheeky behavior: The skateboarders acted with effrontery. skating through the church grounds and spray-painting signs warning trespassers.

egotist.boaster: An egotist, Natasha had few friends because of her inability to talk about anything except her dream of becoming the next American Idol.

egregious.shockingly bad: The dictator's abuse of human rights was so egregious that many world leaders demanded that he be tried in an international court for genocide.

eke.scrape by: Stranded in a cabin over the winter, Terry was able to eke out an existence on canned food.

elaborate.detailed: After returning from Morocco, Thomas replaced his dirty gray carpet with an elaborate one he'd brought back with him.

elegiac.mournful: Few can listen to the elegiac opening bars of the Moonlight sonata without feeling the urge to cry.

elicit.call forth: Just smiling - even if you are depressed - can elicit feelings of pleasure and happiness.

elucidate.make clearer: YouTube is a great place to learn just about anything - an expert elucidates finer points so that even a complete novice can learn.

elude.fail to be grasped: Even a basic understanding of physics can elude most high school students.

elusive.hard to pin down: Many first time skydivers say that describing the act of falling from the sky is elusive

embellish.add details to: McCartney would write relatively straightforward lyrics, and Lennon would embellish them with puns and poetic images.

embroiled.in an argument: These days we are never short of a D.C. politician embroiled in scandal - a welcome phenomenon for those who, having barely finished feasting on the sordid details of one imbroglio, can seek their teeth into a fresh one.

embryonic.undeveloped: The Board of Directors is hoping to launch a new product soon, but planning for the Z7 is in an embryonic stage.

eminent.highly respected: Shakespeare is an eminent author in the English language, but I find his writing uninteresting and melodramatic.

empathetic.relating to feelings of others: Most discrimination and hatred is based on a lack of empathetic awareness of people that have the same aspirations and fears.

empericism.action based on practice: Empiricism does not always lead to knowledge; an experience or experiment may raise more questions than it answers.

emulate.imitate: To really become fluent in a new language, emulate the speech patters of people who speak the language.

enamored.charmed: She is completely enamored of Justin Bieber, and goes to all his concerts on the east coast.

encumber.hold back: The costume encumbered all my movements and caused me to sweat profusely.

endemic.native: Irish cuisine makes great use of potatoes, but ironically, potato is not endemic to Ireland.

enervate.sap energy from: John preferred to avoid equatorial countries; the intense sun would always leave him enervated after he'd spent the day sightseeing.

engender.give rise to: The restrictions of the Treaty of Versailles were so severe that they engendered deep hatred and resentment in the German people.

enjoin.prohibit: The government agency enjoined chemical companies from dumping chemical waste that had not been first securely stored in specially marked containers.

enmity.hate: Charles' rude remark toward Sarah yesterday was due to his illness, not due to any real enmity toward Sarah.

enormity.great wickedness: The enormity of Pol Pot's regime is hard to capture in words - within months hundreds of thousands of Cambodians lost their lives.

enthrall.captivate: She was enthralled by the movie that she never heard people screaming, Fire! Fire! in the neighboring theater.

entice.tempt: Harold enticed his wife, Maude, to go on a vacation to Hawaii, with promises of luaus on the beach and all-you-can-eat seafood buffets.

entrenched.fixed firmly: By the time we reach 60 years old, most of our habits are so entrenched that it is difficult for us to change.

enumerate.determine number of: The 2015 census enumerated 34,587 people living in the province.

ephemeral.short-lived: The lifespan of a mayfly is ephemeral, lasting from a few hours to a couple of days.

epigram.witty saying: My favorite epigram from Mark Twain is 'A man who carries a cat by the tail learns something he can learn no other way'.

epiphany.sudden realization: Gary one day had an epiphany that he was a people person; he promptly quit his factory job and began working as a salesman.

eponym.derived from a name: Alexandria, Egypt is an eponym because it is named after Alexander the Great.

equitable.fair: The equitable distribution of ice cream to a group of 5 year olds will ensure little to no fighting - at least until the ice cream is gone.

equivocal.vague: The findings of the study were equivocal - the two researchers had different opinions on what the results signified.

equivocate.speak vaguely: After Sharon brought the car home an hour after her curfew, she equivocated when her parents pointedly asked her where she had been.

eradicate.destroy completely: I tried eradicating the mosquitoes in my apartment with a rolled up newspaper, but there were too many of them.

err.make a mistake: He erred in thinking that indigent and indignant were synonyms.

errant.straying from course: Unlike his peers, who spent their hours studying in the library, Matthew preferred errant walks through the university campus.

erratic.highly irregular: It came as no surprise to pundits that the President's attempt at reelection floundered; even during his term, support for his policies was erratic, with an approval rating jumping anywhere from 30 to 60 percent.

ersatz.fake: The car dealer's ersatz laughter was immediately followed by a price quote, one that Shelly found highly inflated.

erudite.scholarly: Before the internet, the library was typically where you would find erudite readers.

eschew.avoid: Politicians are the masters of eschewing morals; academics are the masters of eschewing clarity.

esoteric.understood by few: Map collecting is an esoteric hobby to most, but to geography geeks it is a highly enjoyable pastime.

espouse.support a cause: As a college student, Charlie espoused Marxism, growing his beard out and railing against the evils of the free-market.

estimable.deserving respect: After serving thirty years, in which he selflessly served the community, Judge Harper was one of the more estimable people in town.

ethereal.extremely delicate: Because she dances in an ethereal style, ballet critics have called her Madame Butterfly.

euphoria.extreme joy: The euphoria of winning her first gold medal in the 100 meter dash overwhelmed Shelly-Ann Fraser and she wept tears of immense joy.

evanescent.short-lived: The storm flashed into existence above us and lasted only a short time - an evanescent turbulence of wind and cloud.

evasive.avoiding commitment: His responses were clearly evasive; he obviously did not want to take on any responsibility or any new work.

evenhanded.fair, unbiased: Teachers often have trouble being evenhanded to all of their varied students.

exacerbate.make worse: Her sleeplessness exacerbated her cold. When she woke up the next day, her sinuses were completely blocked.

exacting.demanding: Though his childhood piano teacher was so exacting, Max is thankful now, as a professional pianist.

exalt.praise highly: The teenagers exalted the rock star, covering their bedrooms with posters of him.

exasperate.annoy: As a child, I exasperated my mother with strings of never ending questions.

excoriate.criticize harshly: Entrusted with the prototype to his company's latest smartphone, Larry, during a late night Karaoke bout, let the prototype slip into the hands of a rival company - the next day Larry was excoriated, and then fired.

excruciating.very painful: After a boulder rolled a couple of feet, pinning my friend's arm, he experienced excruciating pain.

execrate.curse, hiss at: Though the new sitcom did decently in the ratings, Nelson railed against the show, saying that it was nothing more than an execrable pastiche of tired cliches and canned laughter.

exegesis.critical analysis: The Bible is fertile ground for exegesis - over the past five centuries there have bee as many interpretations as there are pages in The Old Testament.

exemplar.model: Lena's homework is on the wall because it is an exemplar of clean, neat and thoughtful work.

exemplify.be a perfect example of: Lincoln exemplified the best of not only America, but also the potential greatness that exists within each person.

exhort.encourage: Nelson's parents exhorted him to study medicine, urging him to choose a respectable profession; intransigent, Nelson left home to become a graffiti artist.

exiguity.meagerness: After two months at sea, the exiguity of the ship's supplies forced them to search for fresh water and food.

exonerate.free from blame: The document clearly indicated that Nick was out of the state at the time of the crime, and so served to exonerate him of any charges.

exorbitant.excessive: Shelley made one exorbitant purchase after another, buying new clothes and taking vacations even though she earned a limited salary.

expansive.sociable: After a few sips of cognac, the octogenarian shed his irascible demeanor and became expansive, speaking fondly of the 'good old days'.

expound.add details to: The CEO refused to expound on the decision to merge our department with another one, and so I quit.

expunge.erase: When I turned 18, all of the shoplifting and jaywalking charges were expunged from my criminal record.

expurgate.censor: The censor board expurgated every reference to sex and drugs, converting the rapper's raunchy flow into series of bleeps.

extant.still in existence: Despite many bookstores closing, experts predict that some form of book dealing will still be extant generations from now.

extenuating.making less guilty: The jury was hardly moved by the man's plea that his loneliness was an extenuating factor in his crime of dognapping a prized pooch.

extrapolate.estimate or conclude: By extrapolating from the data on the past three months, we can predict a 5% increase in traffic to our website.

facetious.humorous: Facetious behavior will not be tolerated during sex education class; it's time for all of you to treat these matters like mature adults.

facile.lacking depth: Many news shows provide facile explanations to complex politics, so I prefer to read the in-depth reporting of The New York Times.

factious.causing dissension: The controversial bill proved factious, as dissension even within parties resulted.

factitious.artificial: The defendant's story was largely factitious and did not accord with eyewitness testimonies.

fallacious.prone to error: The widespread belief that Eskimos have forty different words for snow is fallacious, based on one false report.

fastidious.fussy: Whitney is fastidious about her shoes, arranging them on a shelf in a specific order, each pair evenly spaced.

fawn.flatter extremely: The media fawned over the handsome new CEO, praising his impeccable sense of style instead of asking more pointed questions.

feckless.lazy, irresponsible: Two years after graduation, Charlie still lived with his parents and had no job, becoming more feckless with each passing day.

fecund.mentally productive: The artist had entered a fecund period, producing three masterpieces in the span of two months.

fell.evil: For fans of the Harry Potter series, the fell Lord Voldemort, who terrorizes poor Harry for seven lengthy installments, has finally been vanquished by the forces of good - unless that is, JK Rowling decides to come out of retirement.

ferret.search for: Even the resourceful lexicographer, Fenton was able to ferret out the word origin of highly obscure words.

fete.celebrate a person: After World War II, war heroes were feted at first but quickly forgotten.

fickle.changing unpredictably: She was so fickle in her politics, it was hard to pinpoint her beliefs; one week she would embrace a side, and the next week she would denounce it.

finagle.get through trickery: Steven was able to finagle one of the last seats on the train by convincing the conductor that his torn stub was actually a valid ticket.

firebrand.troublemaker: Freddie is a firebrand: every time he walks into the office, he winds up at the center of heated argument.

flag.tire: After the three crushing defeats in the last three games, the team's enthusiasm began to flag.

fledgling.inexperienced: Murray has years of experience in family practice, but he is just a fledgling in surgery.

fleece.deceive: Many people have been fleeced by Internet scams and never received their money back.

flippant.not showing respect: Although Sam was trying to honor Mark's sense of humor, many found it quite flippant that he wore a comic nose and glasses mask to Mark's funeral.

flounder.struggle: Sylvia has excelled at advanced calculus, but ironically, when she deals with taxes, she flounders.

flummox.bewilder: Mary's behavior completely flummoxes me: I never have any idea what her motivations might be.

flush.abundant: The exam's passage is flush with difficult words, words that you may have learned only yesterday.

flux.uncertainty: Ever since Elvira resigned as the head of marketing, everything about our sales strategy has been in a state of flux.

foible.small weakness: When their new roommate sat staring at an oak tree for an hour, Marcia thought it indicated a mental problem, but Jeff assured her it was a harmless foible.

foment.stir up, agitate: After having his pay cut, Phil spread vicious rumors about his boss, hoping to foment a general feeling of discontent.

foolhardy.rash: The police regularly face dangerous situations, so for a police officer not to wear bullet-proof vest is foolhardy.

forlorn.hopeless: After her third pet dog died, Marcia was simply forlorn: this time even the possibility of buying a new dog no longer held any joy.

forthcoming.easily available: The president announced that the senators were about reach a compromise, and that he was eager to read the forthcoming details of the bill.

forthright.honest in speaking: I did not expect the insurance agent to give us any straight answers, but I was pleasantly surprised by how forthright he was.

fortuitous.based on chance: Though Maria's neighbor Ernie 'bumped into' her at the Farmer's Market, the encounter wasn't nearly as fortuitous as Maria was led to believe: Ernie desperately wanted to ask Maria out on a date and had been following her about town.

fractious.irritable: We rarely invite my fractious Uncle Nino over for dinner; he always complains about the food, and usually launches into a tirade on some touchy subject.

frivolous.not serious: Compared to Juliet's passionate concern for human rights, Jake's non-stop concern about football seems somewhat frivolous.

frugal.spending wisely: Monte was no miser, but was simply frugal, wisely spending the little that he earned.

frustrate.prevent: I thought I would finish writing the paper by lunchtime, but a number of urgent interruptions served to frustrate my plan.

furtive.stealthy: While at work, George and his boss Regina felt the need to be as furtive as possible about their romantic relationship.

futile.pointless: I thought I could repair the car myself, but after two days of work with no success, I have to admit that my efforts were futile.

gaffe.social blunder: In a famous gaffe, Vice president Quayle attempted to correct the spelling of a grade school student, only to find that the child was correct.

gainsay.speak out against: I can't gainsay a single piece of evidence James has presented, but I still don't trust his conclusion.

gall.rudeness: Even though Carly was only recently hired, she had the gall to question her boss's judgment in front of his office.

galvanize.urge into action: At mile 23 of his first marathon, Kyle had all but given up, until he noticed his friends and family holding a banner that read, 'Go Kyle'; galvanized, he broke into a gallop, finishing the last three miles in less than 20 minutes.

gambit.scheme: Randy played a gambit, telling his boss that he would leave at the end of the week if he didn't get a raise.

garrulous.talkative: Lynne was garrulous: once, she had a fifteen minute conversation with a stranger before she realized the woman didn't speak English.

gauche.clumsy: Sylvester says the most gauche things, such as telling a girl he liked that she was much prettier when she wore makeup.

genial.agreeable: Betty is a genial young woman: everyone she meets is put at ease by her elegance and grace.

genteel.refined: A live string quartet would provide a more genteel air to the wedding than would a folk singer.

germane.relevant: The professor wanted to tell the jury in detail about his new book, but the lawyer said it wasn't germane to the charges in the cases.

gerrymander.manipulate votes: Years ago, savvy politicians had gerrymandered the city center to ensure their re-election.

glean.collect: Herb has given us no formal statement about his background, but from various hints, I have gleaned that he grew up in difficult circumstances.

glib.insincere: I have found that more glib the salesman, the worse the product.

glut.excessive supply: The Internet offers such a glut of news related stories that many find it difficult to know which story to read first.

goad.aggressively urge on: Doug did not want to enter the race, but Jim, through a steady stream of taunts, goaded him into signing up for it.

gossamer.delicate: The gossamer wings of a butterfly, which allow it to fly, are also a curse, so delicate that they are often damaged.

graft.corruption: In countries with rampant graft, getting a driver's license can require no more than paying an official.

grandiloquent.pompous: The dictator was known for his grandiloquent speeches, puffing his chest out and using big, important-sounding words.

gregarious.sociable: Often we think great leaders are those who are gregarious, always in the middle of a large group of people; yet, as Mahatma Gandhi and many others have shown us, leaders can also be introverted.

grovel.show fear: Every time Susan comes to the office, Frank grovels as if she were about to fire him.

guffaw.laugh loudly: Whenever the jester fell to the ground in mock pain, the king guffawed, exposing his yellow, fang-like teeth.

guileless.without deceit: At first I thought my niece was guileless, but then I found myself buying her ice cream every time we passed a shop.

gumption.resourcefulness: Wallace Stegner lamented the lack of gumption in the US during the sixties, claiming that no young person knew the value of work.

hackneyed.cliche: Cheryl rolled her eyes when she heard the lecturer's hackneyed advice to be true to herself.

hagiographic.idealizing a subject: Most accounts of Tiger Woods life were hagiographic, until, that is, his affairs made headlines.

hail.celebrate something: Many college superstar athletes are hailed as the next big thing, but then flop at the  professional level.

halcyon.peaceful: The first decade after WW1 was a halcyon period in America with new-found wealth and rapidly improving technology.

hamper.prevent progress: As the rain water began to collect in pools on the highway, it began to hamper the flow of traffic.

hamstrung.made powerless: The FBI has made so many restrictions on the local police that they are absolutely hamstrung, unable to accomplish anything.

haphazard.unorganized, random: Many golf courses are designed with great care, but the greens on the county golf course seem entirely haphazard.

harangue.aggressive speech: Dinner at Billy's was more a punishment than a reward, since anyone who sat at the dinner table would have to listen to Billy's father's interminable harangues against the government.

harried.troubled persistently: With a team of new hires to train, Martha was constantly harried with little questions and could not focus on her projects.

haughty.arrogant: The haughty manager didn't believe that any of his subordinates could ever have an insight ass brilliant as his own.

hauteur.extreme pride: As soon as she won the lottery, Alice began displaying a hauteur to her friends, calling them dirty-clothed peasants behind their backs.

hector.bully: The boss's hectoring manner put off many employees, some of whom quit as soon as they found new jobs.

hedge.limit a statement: When asked why he had decided to buy millions of shares at the very moment the tech companies stock soared, the CEO hedged, mentioning something vague about gut instinct.

hegemony.dominance: Until the Spanish Armada was defeated in 1587, Spain had hegemony over the seas, controlling waters stretching as far as the Americas.

heretic.dissenter: Though everybody at the gym told Mikey to do cardio before weights, Mikey was a heretic and always did the reverse.

heyday.pinnacle: During the heyday of Prohibition, bootlegging had become such a lucrative business that many who had been opposed to the 18th Amendment began to fear it would be repealed.

histrionic.overly theatrical: Though she received a B- on the test, she had such a histrionic outburst that one would have thought that she'd been handed a death sentence.

hoary.ancient: Most workout gurus are young, fit people, whereas most yoga gurus are hoary men with long white beards.

hobbled.hold back: Bad weather has hobbled rescue efforts, making it difficult for crews to find bodies in the wreckage.

hodgepodge.mixture: Those in attendance represented a hodgepodge of city's denizens: chimney sweepers could be seen sitting elbow to elbow with stockbrokers.

hoodwink.deceive: Someone tried to hoodwink Marty with an email telling him that his uncle had just passed away, and to collect the inheritance he should send his credit card information.

hound.pursue relentlessly: An implacable foe of corruption, Eliot Ness hounded out graft in all forms - he even helped nab Al Capone.

hubris.excessive pride: Bill Clinton was criticized for his hubris, since he believed he could get away with anything once in the White House.

humdrum.lacking excitement: Having grown up in a humdrum suburb, Jacob relished life in New York city after moving.

iconoclast.attacker of beliefs: Lady Gaga, in challenging what it means to be clothed, is an iconoclast for wearing a meat dress to a prominent award show.

iconoclastic.defying tradition: Jackson Pollack was an iconoclastic artist, totally breaking with tradition by splashing paint on a blank canvas.

idiosyncrasy.peculiarity: Peggy's numerous idiosyncrasies include wearing mismatched shoes, laughing loudly to herself, and owning a pet aardvark.

ignoble.dishonorable: In the 1920s, the World Series was rigged - an ignoble act which baseball took decades to recover from.

ignominious.disgraceful: Since the politician preached ethics and morality, his texting of revealing photographs was ignominious, bringing shame on both himself and his party.

illustrious.famous: Einstein was possibly the most illustrious scientist in recent history.

imbibe.absorb ideas: Plato imbibed Socrates' teaching to such an extent that he was able to write volumes of work that he directly attributed, sometimes word for word, to Socrates.

imbroglio.confusing situation: The chef cook-off featured one gourmand who had the unfortunate distinction of mixing the wrong broths, creating an imbroglio that diners would not soon forget.

immaterial.irrelevant: The judge found the defendant's comments immaterial to the trial, and summarily dismissed him from the witness stand.

immure.confine: The modern supermarket experience makes many feel claustrophobic, as they are immured in walls upon walls of products.

immutable.not changeable: Taxes are one of the immutable laws of the land, so there is no use arguing about paying them.

impartial.unbiased: The judge was not impartial since he had been bribed by the witness's family.

impeccable.flawless: He was impeccably dressed in the latest fashion without a single crease or stain.

impecunious.lacking money: In extremely trying times, even the moderately wealthy, after a few turns of ill-fortune, can become impecunious.

impede.slow down: Since the police sergeant had to train the pair of new hires. progress in his own case was impeded.

impending.about to happen: The impending doom of our world has been discussed and debated for over 2000 years - maybe even longer.

imperious.domineering: Children are imperious with each other before they learn that earning someone's respect is better than demanding.

impermeable.sealed: The sand bags placed on the river formed an impermeable barrier, protecting the town from flooding.

impertinent.disrespectful: Dexter, distraught over losing his pet dachshund, Madeline, found the police officer's questions impertinent - after all, he thought, did she have to pry into such details as to what Madeline's favorite snack was?

impervious.unaffected by: I am not impervious to your insults; they cause me great pain.

impetuous.rash: Herbert is rarely impetuous, but on the spur of the moment, he spent thousands of dollars on a motorcycle today.

implacable.unable to be calmed: Win or lose, the coach was always implacable, never giving the athletes an easy practice or a break.

implausible.unbelievable: The teacher found it implausible that the student was late to school because he had been kidnapped by outlaws on horseback.

implicate.convey meaning: By saying that some of the guests were uncomfortable, the manager implicated to the hotel staff that it needed to be more diligent.

imponderable.difficult to assess: According to many lawmakers, the huge variety of factors affecting society make devising an efficient health care system an imponderable task.

importuned.asked persistently: After weeks of importuning the star to meet for a five-minute interview, the journalist finally got what she wanted.

impregnable.indestructible: As a child, Amy would build pillow castles and pretend they were impregnable fortresses.

improvident.not careful: Marty was improvident, never putting money aside for the future but spending it on decorating the interior of his home.

imprudent.not wise: Hitler, like Napoleon, made the imprudent move of invading Russia in winter, suffering even more casualties than Napoleon had.

impudent.rude: In an impudent move, the defendant spoke out of order to say terribly insulting things to the judge.

impugn.call into question: Though many initially tried to impugn Darwin's theory, in scientific circles today, the idea is taken as truth.

impute.attribute: He imputed his subpar performance on the test to a combination of stress and poor sleep.

inadvertent.unintentional: Although Prohibition was rooted in noble ideas, the inadvertent and costly consequences of making alcohol illegal in the US led to its repeal.

inanity.silliness: Bill's poem was nothing more than a list of impressive sounding words, so there was no point in trying to take meaning from the inanity.

inarticulate.not speaking clearly: Although a brilliant economist, Professor Black was completely inarticulate, a terrible lecturer.

incense.make furious: When Herb bought football tickets for a game on the day of their wedding anniversary, Jill was incensed.

incessant.not stopping: I don't mind small children in small doses, but I think the incessant exposure that their parents have to them would quickly wear me down.

inchoate.not fully formed: Inchoate ideas about the relation of humans to other animals had been discussed since the middle ages but the modern theory really began with Darwin.

incisive.highly analytical: The lawyer had an incisive mind, able in a flash to dissect a hopeless tangled issue and isolate the essential laws at play.

inclement.lacking mercy: The judge, inclement as always, gave the prisoner - despite all the tears - a full sentence.

incongruous.lacking harmony: The vast economic inequality of modern society is incongruous with America's ideals.

incontrovertible.undisputable: Unless you can provide incontrovertible evidence, I will remain skeptical.

incorrigible.not reformable: Tom Sawyer seems like an incorrigible youth until Huck Finn enters the novel; even Sawyer can't match his fierce individual spirit.

incumbent.necessary: Middle managers at times make important decisions, but real responsibility for the financial well-being of the corporation is ultimately incumbent on the CEO.

indecorous.impolite: Eating with elbows on the table is considered indecorous in refined circles.

indict.accuse formally: The bank robber was indicted on several major charges, including possession of a firearm.

indifference.apathy: In an effort to fight indifference, the president of the college introduced a new, stricter grading system.

indigenous.native to: The plants and animals indigenous to Australia are notably different from those indigenous to the US - one look at a duckbill platypus and you know you are not dealing with an opossum.

indigent.poor: In the so-called Third World, many are indigent and only a privileged few have the resources to enjoy material luxuries.

indignant.angry: When the cyclist swerved into traffic, it forced the driver to brake and elicited an indignant shout of 'Hey, punk, watch where you are going!'.

industrious.hard-working: Pete was an industrious student, completing every assignment thoroughly and on time.

ineffable.can't be put in words: While art critics can occasionally pinpoint a work's greatness, much of why a piece captures our imaginations is completely ineffable.

ineluctable.unavoidable: For those who smoke cigarettes for years, a major health crisis brought on by smoking is ineluctable.

inequity.unfairness: After decades of racial inequity, the separate but equal doctrine was successfully overturned.

inexorable.impossible to stop: The rise of the computer was an inexorable shift in technology and culture.

infelicitous.inappropriate: During the executive meeting, the marketing director continued to make infelicitous comments about the CEO's gambling habit.

inflammatory.controversial: It only takes one person to leave an inflammatory comment on an Internet thread for that thread to blow up into pages upon pages of reader indignation.

ingenuity.cleverness: Daedalus was famous for his ingenuity; he was able to fashion his son Icarus with a pair of wings, using wax to hold them together.

ingenuous.naive: Two-years in Manhattan had changed Jenna from an ingenuous girl from the suburbs to a jaded urbanite, unlikely to fall for any ruse, regardless of how elaborate.

ingratiate.seek favor from another: Even though Tom didn't like his new boss, he decided to ingratiate himself to her in order to advance his career.

inimical.hostile: Venus, with a surface temperature that would turn rubber to liquid, is inimical to any form of life.

inimitable.without equal: Mozart's music follows a clear pattern that, anyone could imitate, but his music gives an overall sense of effortlessness that is inimitable.

inkling.vague sense: Lynne speaks four Romance languages, but she doesn't have an inkling about how East Asian languages are constructed.

innocuous.harmless: Everyone found Nancy's banter innocuous - except for Mike, who felt she was intentionally picking on him.

inscrutable.unfathomable: His speech was so dense and confusing that many in the audience found it inscrutable.

insidious.subtly destructive: Plaque is insidious: we cannot see it, but each day it eats away at our enamel, causing cavities and other dental problems.

insipid.dull, bland: The movie director was known for hiring beautiful actors in order to deflect attention away from the insipid scripts he would typically use.

insolent.rude: Lilian could not help herself from being insolent, commenting that the Queen's shoes were showing too much toe.

insolvent.bankrupt: With credit card bills skyrocketing, a shockingly large number of Americans are truly insolvent.

insouciance.lack of concern: Surprisingly, Hank had become a high-powered CEO; his high school friends remembered him as Hanky Panky, who shrugged off each failed class with insouciance.

insufferable.unbearable: Chester always tried to find some area in which he excelled above others; unsurprisingly, his co-workers found him insufferable and chose to exclude him from daily luncheons out.

intermittent.occurring on and off: The intermittent thunder continued and the night was punctuated by cracks of lightning - a surreal sleepless night.

internecine.marked by internal strife: The guerrilla group, which had become so powerful as to own the state police, was finally destroyed by an internecine conflict.

intimate.hint at: At first Manfred's teachers intimated to his parents that he was not suited to skip a grade; when his parents protested, teachers explicitly told them that, notwithstanding the boy's precocity, he was simply too immature to jump to the sixth grade.

intimation.indirect suggestion: At first the hostess tried intimation, praising the benefits of cutlery; when Cecil continued eating with his hands, the hostess told him to use a fork at dinner.

intransigent.stubborn: Despite many calls for mercy, the judge remained intransigent, citing strict legal precedence.

intrepid.fearless: Captain Ahab was an intrepid captain whose reckless and fearless style ultimately leads to his downfall.

inundate.flood: The newsroom was inundated with false reports that only made it more difficult for the newscasters to provide an objective account of the bank robbery.

inure.harden: Three years of Manhattan living has inured her to the sound of wailing sirens; she could probably sleep through the apocalypse.

invective.abusive language: The internet has unleashed the invectives in many of us; many people post stinging criticism on the comment section underneath newspaper articles or YouTube videos.

inveterate.habitual: He is an inveterate smoker and has told his family and friends that there is no way he will ever quit.

invidious.causing resentment: At a time when many others in the office were about to be laid off, many considered Cheryl's fine clothes that day an invidious display.

inviolable.sacred: To many the grass at Wimbledon is inviolable and only greater tennis players are able to enjoy a game there.

inviolate.sacred: While the literary critic subjected most of the classics to the harshest reviews, he regarded Cervantes as inviolate, and had nothing but praise for him.
