involved.complicated: The physics lecture became so involved that the undergraduate's eyes glazed over.

irascible.easily angered: If Arthur's dog is not fed adequately, he becomes highly irascible, even growling at his own shadow.

irk.annoy: My little sister has a way of irking and annoying me like no other person.

irrefutable.certain: The existence of life on earth is irrefutable; the existence of intelligent life on earth is still hotly debated.

irresolute.uncertain how to act: He stood irresolute at the split in the trail, not sure which route would lead back to camp.

irrevocable.not able to be changed: Once you enter your plea to the court, it is irrevocable so think carefully about what you will say.

itinerant.traveling: Doctors used to be itinerant, traveling between patients' homes.

jargon.speech particular to a group: To those with little training in medicine, the jargon of doctors can be very difficult to understand.

jaundice.bias: Shelly was jaundiced towards Olivia; though the two had once been best friends, Olivia had became class president, prom queen, and, to make matters worse, the girlfriend of the boy Shelly liked.

jejune.immature: Although many top chefs have secured culinary foam's popularity in haute cuisine, Waters criticizes it for being jejune and unfilling.

jingoism.fanatical patriotism: North Korea maintains intense control over its population through a combination of jingoism and cult of personality.

jingoist.overly patriotic: In the days leading up to war, a nation typically breaks up into two opposing camps: doves, who do their best to avoid war, and jingoists, who are only too eager to wave national flags from their vehicles and vehemently denounce those who do not do the same.

jocular.humorous: My uncle was always in a jocular mood at family gatherings, messing up people's hair and telling knock-knock jokes to anyone who would listen.

jovial.merry: The presidential candidate and her supporters were jovial once it was clear that she had won.

jubilant.overjoyed: My hard-work paid off, and I was jubilant to receive a perfect score on the GRE.

juggernaut.unstoppable force: Once considered a juggernaut, Napoleon's army was finally stopped by the Russians.

junta.group seizing power: As dangerous of a threat North Korea is, some analysts believe that were a junta suddenly to gain power, it would be even more unpredictable and bellicose than the current leadership.

juxtapose.place side by side: The appeal of her paintings comes from a classical style which is juxtaposed with modern themes.

kowtow.bow to: Paul kowtowed to his boss so often the boss herself became nauseated by his sycophancy.

laborious.demanding: The most laborious job I've had was working 20 hours a day as a fisherman in Alaska.

lacerate.distress deeply: The teacher was fired for lacerating a student who wrote a poor essay.

lachrymose.weepy: Lachrymose and depressed, Alexei Alexandrovich walked two miles home in the rain after learning that his wife was having an affair.

laconic.not saying much: While Martha always swooned over the hunky, laconic types in romantic comedies, her boyfriends inevitably were very talkative - and not very hunky.

lambast.criticize severely: Showing no patience, the manager utterly lambasted the sales team that lost the big account.

lampoon.poke fun at: Mark Twain understood that lampooning a bad idea with humor was the most effective criticism.

languid.tired: As the sun beat down and the temperature climbed higher, we spent a languid week lying around the house.

languish.become weak: Stranded in the wilderness for four days, the hiker languished, eating protein bars and nuts.

largess.generosity: Uncle Frank was known for his largess, so his nephew was sad when he did not receive a present for his birthday.

lascivious.perverted: Lolita is a challenging novel for many, not necessarily because of the elevated prose style but because of the depravity of the main character, Humbert Humbert, who, as an old, lascivious man, falls in love with a girl.

laudable.praiseworthy: To say that Gandhi's actions were laudable is the greatest understatement, he overthrew an empire without violence.

leery.distrustful: Without checking his references and talking to previous employers, I am leery of hiring the candidate.

lethargic.weary: Nothing can make a person more lethargic than a big turkey dinner.

limpid.clear: Her limpid prose made even the most recondite subjects accessible to all.

lionize.celebrate: Students in the US learn to lionize Jefferson, Franklin, and Washington because they are the founding fathers of the nation.

litany.long account: Mr. Rogers spoke to a Senate committee and did not give a litany of reasons to keep funding the program, but instead, appealed to the basic human decency of all present.

loath.reluctant: I was loath to leave the concert before my favorite band finished playing.

lucid.easy to understand: Though Walters writes about physics and time travel, his writing is always lucid, so readers with little scientific training can understand difficult concepts.

lugubrious.overly sad: At the funeral, lugubrious songs filled the small church.

macabre.gruesome: Edgar Allen Poe was considered the master of macabre; his stories vividly describe the moment leading up to - and often those after - a grisly death.

machinate.scheme: The rebels met at night in an abandoned barn to machinate.

magisterial.domineering: Though she was only a third grade teacher, Ms. Martinet was magisterial in dealing with her class, lording over them like a queen.

magnanimous.likely to forgive: He was a great sportsman: in defeat he was complementary and in victory he was magnanimous.

maintain.assert: The scientist maintained that the extinction of dinosaurs was most likely brought about by a drastic change in climate.

maladroit.clumsy: As a child she was quite maladroit, but as an adult, she has become an adept dancer.

malady.illness: The town was struck by a malady throughout the winter that left most people sick in bed for two weeks.

malapropism.confusing similar words: Whenever I looked glum, my mother would offer to share an amusing 'antidote' with me - an endearing malapropism of anecdote that never failed to cheer me up.

malevolent.evil-minded: Villains are known for their malevolent nature, often times inflicting cruelty on others just for enjoyment.

malfeasance.misconduct: Not even the mayor's trademark pearly-toothed grin could save him from charges of malfeasance: while in power, he'd been running an illegal gambling ring in the room behind his office.

malinger.avoid work: At one time, our country was full of hardworking respectful people, but now it seems that everyone is a malingerer with little inclination to work.

malleable.moldable: The clay became malleable and easy to work with after a little water was added.

malodorous.stinky: Some thermally active fountains spew sulfur fumes - the air around them is sometimes so malodorous that many have to plug their noses.

martial.warlike: Americans tend to remember Abraham Lincoln as kindly and wise, not at all martial, despite the fact that he was involved in the fiercest war America has even fought.

martinet.disciplinarian: The job seemed perfect to Rebecca, until she found out that her boss was a total martinet; after each project the boss would come by to scrutinize - and inevitably criticize - every little detail of the work Rebecca had done.

maudlin.overly emotional: Just as those who were alive during the 70's are mortified that they once cavorted about in bell bottoms, many who lived during the 80's are now aghast at the maudlin pop songs they used to enjoy - really, just what exactly is a total eclipse of the heart?

maunder.wander: Max liked to maunder down by the seaside and pick up whatever sea shells he would stumble upon.

maverick.radical thinker: Officer Kelly was a maverick, rarely following police protocols or adopting the conventions for speech common among his fellow officers.

mawkish.overly sentimental: The film was incredibly mawkish, introducing highly likeable characters only to have them succumb to a devastating illnesses by the end of the movie.

maxim.short saying: Johnson initially suggests that the secret to business can be summarized in a single maxim but then requires a 300 page book to explain exactly what he means.

meander.wander: A casual observer might have thought that Peter was meandering through the city, but that day he was actually seeking out those places where he and his long lost love once visited.

melancholy.sadness: Hamlet is a figure of tremendous melancholy: he doesn't have a truly cheerful scene throughout the entire play.

melee.wild fight: After enduring daily taunts about my name, I became enraged and pummeled the schoolyard bully and his sycophantic friends in a brutal melee.

mellifluous.sweet-sounding: Chelsea's grandmother thought Franz Schubert's music to be the most mellifluous ever written; Chelsea demurred, and to her grandmother's chagrin, would blast Rihanna on the home stereo speakers.

mendacity.deceit: I can forgive her for her mendacity but only because she is a child and is seeing what she can get away with.

mendicant.beggar: Tolstoy was an aristocrat, but he strove to understand the Christianity of the Russian peasants by wandering among them as a mendicant.

mercurial.emotionally changing: The fact that Ella's moods were as mercurial as the weather was problematic for her relationships - it didn't help that she lived in Chicago.

mesmerize.hypnotize: The plot and the characters were so well developed that many viewers were mesmerized, unable to move their eyes from the screen for even a single second.

meteoric.very rapid: The early spectacular successes propelled the pitcher to meteoric stardom, but a terrible injury tragically cut short his career.

meticulous.detail oriented: The Japanese noodle maker was meticulous in making his noodles and would never let another person take over the task.

mettlesome.courageous: For its raid on the Bin Laden's compound in Abbottabad, Seal Team Six has become, for many Americans, the embodiment of mettle.

misanthrope.hater of people: Kevin is such a misanthrope that he refused to attend the Christmas party, claiming that everyone's happiness was fake and annoying.

misattribute.misidentify: I made a mistake; I misattributed Crime and Punishment to Leo Tolstoy when it was actually written by Fyodor Dostoyevskey.

misconstrue.misinterpret: The politician never trusted journalists because he thought that they would misconstrue his words and misrepresent his positions.

miscreant.lawbreaker: Come back you miscreant! yelled the woman who just had her purse stolen.

miser.one who is cheap: Monte was no miser, but was simply frugal, wisely spending the little that he earned.

misogynist.hater of woman: Many have accused Hemingway of being a quiet misogynist, but recently unearthed letters argue against this belief.

mitigate.lessen severity of: I can only spend so much time mitigating your disagreements with your wife, and at certain point, you need to do it on your own.

modicum.a small amount: If my sister had even a modicum of sense, she wouldn't be engaged to that barbarian.

mollify.soothe: In the morning, Harriat was unable to mollify Harry, if he happened to become angry, unless he had his cup of coffee.

moment.importance: Despite the initial hullabaloo, the play was of no great moment in Hampton's writing career, and within a few years the public quickly forgot his foray into theater arts.

moot.irrelevant: Since the Board just terminated Steve as the CEO, the finance committee's opinion of his marketing plan for next year is now moot.

mordant.biting, caustic: While Phil frequently made mordant remarks about company policy overall, he always was considerably gentler in discussing any person in particular.

moribund.about to die: Whether you like it or not, jazz as a genre is moribund at best, possibly already dead.

morose.gloomy: After Stanley found out he was no longer able to go on vacation with his friends, he sat in his room morosely.

morph.change dramatically: The earnestness of the daytime talk shows of the 1970s has morphed into something far more sensational and vulgar: today guests actually stand up and threaten to take swings at one another.

mulct.swindle: The so-called magical diet cure simply ended up mulcting Maria out of hundreds of dollars, but did nothing for her weight.

mundane.routine: Nancy found doing dishes a thoroughly mundane task, although Peter found a kind of Zen pleasure in the chore.

munificent.very generous: Uncle Charley was known for his munificence, giving all seven of his nephews lavish Christmas presents each year.

muted.softened: Helen preferred muted earth colors, such as green and brown, to the bright pinks and red her sister liked.

myopic.shortsighted: The company ultimately went out of business because the myopic managers couldn't predict the changes in their industry.

myriad.large number: There are a myriad of internet sites hawking pills that claim to boost energy for hours on end.

nadir.lowest point: For many pop music fans, the rap and alternative-rock dominated 90s were nadir of musical expression.

negligible.insignificant: The GRE tests cumulative knowledge, so if you cram the night before it is, at best, likely to only have a negligible impact on your score.

nettlesome.annoying: Maria found her coworker's cell phone nettlesome, because every few minutes it would buzz to life with another text message.

noisome.foul-smelling: Each August when the wind moves in a south easternly direction, the garbage dump would spread noisome vapors through the small town.

nonchalant.appearing unconcerned: The twenty-somethings at the coffee shop always irked Sheldon, especially the way in which they acted nonchalantly towards everything, not even caring when Sheldon once spilled his mocha on them.

nonplussed.unsure how to act: Shirley was totally nonplussed when the angry motorist cut her off and then stuck his finger out the window.

nuance.subtlety: Because of the nuances involved in this case, I hired an outside consultant to advise us and help.

obdurate.stubborn: No number of pleas and bribes would get him to change his obdurate attitude.

objurgate.scold severely: The manager spent an hour objurgating the employee in the hopes that he would not make these mistakes again.

obliging.eager to help: Even after all his success, I found him to be accommodating and obliging, sharing with me his secret tips on how to gain wealth and make friends.

oblique.indirect: Herbert never explicitly revealed anything negative about Tom's past, but at times he would obliquely suggest that Tom was not as innocent as he seemed.

obscure.hide from view: On the Smith's drive through the Grand Canyon, Mr. Smith's big head obscured much of Mrs. Robinson's view, so that she only saw momentary patches of red rock.

obsequious.overly obedient: The obsequious waiter did not give the couple a moment's peace all through the meal, constantly returning to their table to refill their water glasses and to tell them what a handsome pair they made.

obstinate.stubborn: The coach suggested improvements Sarah might make on the balance beam, but she remained obstinate, unwilling to modify any of the habits that made her successful in the past.

obstreperous.noisily defiant: When the teacher asked the obstreperous student simply to bus his tray, the student threw the entire tray on the floor, shouted an epithet, and walked out.

obtain.be customary: The custom of waiting your turn in line does not obtain in some countries, in which many people try to rush to front of the line at the same time.

obtuse.slow to learn: Jackson was the most obtuse member of the team: the manager's subtle ironies were always lost on him.

officious.meddlesome: The professor had trouble concentrating on her new theorem, because her officious secretary would barge in frequently, reminding her of some trivial detail involving departmental paperwork.

opaque.tough to understand: The meaning of the professor's new research was opaque to most people, so no one asked any questions.

opulence.wealth: Russian oligarchs are famous for their opulence, living in fancy homes and dining on expensive caviar.

ornate.elaborately decorated: The ornate Victorian and Edwardian homes spread throughout San Francisco are my favorite part of the city.

ossify.harden: Even as a young man, Bob had some bias against poor people, but during his years in social services, his bad opinions ossified into unshiftable views.

ostentatious.showy: Matt wanted to buy stone lions for front of the house, but Cynthia convinced him that such a display would be too ostentatious for a modest house in an unassuming neighborhood.

ostracize.exclude: Later in his life, Leo Tolstoy was ostracized from the Russian Orthodox Church for his writings that contradicted church doctrine.

overweening.extremely proud: Mark was so convinced of his basketball skills that in his overweening pride he could not fathom that his name was not on the varsity list; he walked up to the basketball coach and told her she had forgotten to add his name.

palatable.acceptable: Mikey didn't partake much in his friends' conversations, but found their presence palatable.

palaver.babble: During the rain delay, many who had come to see the game palavered, probably hoping that idle chatter would make the time go by faster.

palimpsest.something reused: The downtown was a palimpsest of the city's checkered past: a new Star-bucks had opened up next to an abandoned, shuttered building, and a freshly asphalted road was inches away from a pothole large enough to swallow a small dog.

panacea.cure-all: While the company credit card has made most large purchases easier, it is no panacea: some smaller basic transactions still must be conducted in cash.

panache.distinctive style: Jim, with his typical panache, came to the wedding reception with a top hat, a cane, and a long cape covered in sequins

panegyric.formal praise: Dave asked Andrew to do just a simple toast, but Andrew launched into a full panegyric, enumerating a complete list of Dave's achievements and admirable qualities.

paradoxical.contradictory but true: That light could be both a particle and a wave seems paradoxical, but nonetheless, it is true.

paragon.the best of its kind: Even with the rise of Kobe Bryant, many still believe that Michael Jordan is the paragon of basketball players.

pariah.outcast: The once eminent scientist, upon being found guilty of faking his data, has become a pariah in the research community.

parochial.narrow-minded: Jasmine was sad to admit it, but her fledgling relationship with Jacob did not work out because his culinary tastes were simply too parochial; After all, she quipped on her blog, he considered Chef Boyardee ethnic food.

parsimonious.miserly: Katie is so parsimonious that she only buys a pair of socks if all of her other socks have holes in them.

parvenu.upstart: The theater was full of parvenus who each thought that they were surrounded by true aristocrats.

pastoral.rural: Those who imagine America's countryside as a pastoral region are often disappointed to learn that much of the rural US is filled with cornfields extending as far as the eye can see.

patent.glaringly obvious: Since the book had been through no fewer than six proof runs, the staff was shocked to see such a patent spelling mistake remaining, right in the middle of the front cover!

patronize.treat condescendingly: She says she genuinely wanted to help me, but instead she patronized me, constantly pointing out how I was inferior to her.

paucity.lack of: There is paucity of jobs hiring today that require menial skills, since most jobs have been automated or outsourced.

pecuniary.relating to money: The defendant was found guilty and had to serve a period of community service as well as pay pecuniary damages to the client.

pedantic.showing off learning: Professor Thompson was regarded as an expert in his field, but his lectures were utterly pedantic, focused on rigorous details of the most trivial conventions.

pedestrian.lacking imagination: While Nan was always engaged in philosophical speculation, her brother was occupied with far more pedestrian concerns: how to earn a salary and run a household.

peevish.irritable: Our office manager is peevish, so the rest of us tip-toe around him, hoping no to set off another one of his fits.

pejorative.disapproving: Most psychologists object to pejorative term shrink, believing that they expand the human mind, not limit it.

pellucid.easy to understand: The professor had a remarkable ability to make even the most difficult concepts seem pellucid.

penurious.poor: Truly penurious, Mary had nothing more than a jar full of pennies.

percipient.perceptive: Even the most percipient editor will make an occasional error when proofreading.

peremptory.bossy: My sister used to peremptorily tell me to do the dishes, a chore I would either do perfunctorily or avoid altogether.

perennial.everlasting: Even at the old-timers games, Stan Musial would get the loudest cheer: he was a perennial favorite of the fans there.

perfidy.betrayal: The lowest circles in Dante's Inferno were for those who had practiced perfidy, and among these, the very lowest was for those, such as Judas, who had been treacherous to one of their benefactors.

perfunctory.done routinely: The short film examines modern perfunctory cleaning rituals such as washing dishes, doing laundry and tooth-brushing.

peripatetic.traveling on foot: Jim always preferred a peripatetic approach to discovering a city: he felt that he could see so many more details while walking.

pernicious.harmful: The most successful viruses are pernicious: an infected person may feel perfectly healthy for several months while incubating and spreading the virus.

perpetuate.make happen indefinitely: If you do not let him do things for himself, you are merely perpetuating bad habits that will be even harder to break in the future.

perquisite.exclusive right: Even as the dishwasher at the French restaurant, Josh quickly learned that he had the perquisite of being able to eat terrific food for half the price diners would pay.

perspicacious.very insightful: Many modern observers regard Eisenhower as perspicacious, particularly in his accurate prediction of the growth of the military.

pertinent.relevant: While the salaries of the players might draw attention in the media, such monetary figures are not pertinent to the question of who plays best on the field.

perturb.disturb: Now that Henry is recovering from a major illness, he no longer lets the little trivialities such as late mail, perturb him.

peruse.read closely: Instead of perusing important documents, the people all too often rush to the bottom of the page and plaster their signatures.

petulant.easily annoyed: When Ed first met Ruth, he didn't realize she was so petulant, but now that they are three months into their relationship, Ed feels a day doesn't go by in which she isn't whining about some minor issue.

phantasmagorical.illusive: Those suffering from malaria fall into a feverish sleep, their world a whirligig of phantasmagoria; if they recover, they are unsure of what actually took place and what was simply a product of their febrile imaginations.

philistine.hater of culture: Jane considered Al completely philistine, because he almost talked exclusively about video games; she was entirely unaware of how read he really was.

phlegmatic.not showing emotion: Arnold is truly noble, remaining reserved until an issue of significance arises, but Walter is simply phlegmatic: he doesn't have the energy or inclination to care about anything.

picayune.trifling, petty: English teachers are notorious for being picayune; however, the English language is so nuanced and sophisticated that often such teachers are not being contrary but are only adhering to the rules.

pillory.ridicule publicly: After the candidate confessed, the press of the opposing party took the opportunity to pillory him, printing editorials with the most blatantly exaggerated accusations.

pine.yearn for: Standing forlornly by the window, she pined for her lost love.

pinnacle.highest point: At its pinnacle, the Roman Empire extended across most of the landmass of Eurasia, a feat not paralleled to the rise of the British Empire in the 18th and 19th century.

piquant.pungent in taste: The chef, with a mere flick of the salt shaker, turned the bland tomato soup into a piquant meal.

pith.most essential part: When Cynthia hears a speaker presenting a complex argument, she is always able to discard the irrelevant details and extract the pith of what the speaker is trying to convey.

pithy.concise yet expressive: I enjoy reading the Daodejing for its pithy and insightful prose' it always gives me something to think about.

pittance.small amount: Vinny's uncle beamed smugly about how he had offered his nephew fifty dollars for his Harvard tuition; even twice the amount would have been a mere pittance.

placate.make less angry: I was able to placate the angry mob of students by promising to bring cookies on Monday.

placid.peaceful: Doug is normally placid, so we were all shocked to see him yelling at the television when the Mets lost the game.

platitude.obvious remark: The professor argued that many statements regarded as wise in previous times, such as the Golden Rule, are now regarded as platitude.

plodding.slow-moving: Charlie may seem to run at a plodding pace, but he is an ultra-marathoner, meaning he runs distances of up to 100 miles, and can run for ten hours at a stretch.

ploy.clever scheme: Dennis arranged an elaborate ploy, involving 14 different people lying for him in different situations, so that it could appear that he was meeting Mary completely by chance at the wedding reception.

plucky.courageous: Some scouts initially doubted Pedroia because of his short stature, but he is a plucky player, surprising everyone with his boundless energy and fierce determination.

poignant.emotionally touching: After the Montagues and Capulets discover the dead bodies of Romeo and Juliet, in the play's most poignant moment, the two grief-stricken families agree to end their feud once and for all.

polemic.verbal attack: The professor launched into a polemic, claiming that Freudian theory was a pack of lies that absolutely destroyed European literary theory.

pollyannaish.overly optimistic: Even in the midst of a lousy sales quarter, Debbie remained pollyannaish, never losing her shrill voice and wide smile, even when prospective customers hung up on her.

ponderous.moving slowly: Laden with 20 kilograms of college text books, the freshman moved ponderously across the campus.

pontificate.speak pompously: The vice-president would often pontificate about economic theory, as if no one else in the room were qualified to speak on the topic.

portentous.prophetic: When the captain and more than half the officers were sick on the very first night of the voyage, many of the passengers felt this portentous, bu the rest of the voyage continued without any problems.

posit.assume as a fact: Initially, Einstein posited a repulsive force to balance Gravity, but then rejected the idea as a blunder.

pragmatic.practical: Rather than make a philosophical appeal to the Congressmen, the Speaker decided to take a far more pragmatic approach, making small side-deals that would add votes to his bill.

precarious.dangerous: People smoke to relax and forget their cares, but ironically, in terms of health risks, smoking is far more precarious than either mountain-climbing or skydiving.

precedent.earlier example: The principal explained that even though one student had done modeling work outside of school, the outfits that students wore in those photographs in no way established a precedent for what could be worn at school dances.

precipitate.hasty: Instead of conducting a thorough investigation after the city hall break-in, the governor acted precipitately, accusing his staff of aiding and abetting the criminals.

precipitous.hasty: Instead of calling his financial advisor, Harold acted precipitously, buying 4000 shares of the latest hot stock, only to find out that the company had a history of inflating its year end numbers.

preclude.prevent: The manager specified that all other gates be locked, to preclude the possibility of persons without tickets entering the arena undetected.

precocious.developing early: Though only seven years old, she was a precocious chess prodigy, able to beat players twice her age.

predilection.strong liking: Monte had a predilection for the fine things in life: Cuban cigars, 200 dollar bottles of wine, and trips to the French Riviera.

preempt.take the place of: A governmental warning about an imminent terrorist attack would preempt ordinary network programming on television.

preemptive.done first: Just as Martha was about to take the only cookie left on the table, Noah preemptively swiped it.

prescience.able to foresee future: Baxter's warnings about investing in technology stocks seemed like an act of prescience after the whole market declined significantly.

presentiment.sense of the future: On the night that Lincoln would be fatally shot, his wife had a presentiment about going to Ford's Theater, but Lincoln persuaded her that everything would be fine.

presumption.assumption: When Mr. Baker found out the family car was gone, he acted under the presumption that his rebellious son had taken the car, and yelled at him; only later did Mr. Baker realize that Mrs. Baker had simply gone out to get her nails done.

presumptuous.overly forward: Many felt that Barney was presumptuous in moving into the large office before the management even made any official announcement of his promotion.

prevail.triumph over: During the labor negotiations, an air of hostility prevailed in the office.

prevaricate.speak evasively: The cynic quipped, 'There is not much variance in politicians; they all seem to prevaricate.

primacy.of greatest importance: The primacy of Apple computers is not guaranteed, as seen in the recent lawsuits and weak growth.

pristine.spotless: The glacial lake was pristine and we filled our canteens to drink deeply.

probity.integrity: The ideal politician would have the probity to lead, but reality gravely falls short of the ideal of morally upright leaders.

prodigal.wasteful: Successful professional athletes who do not fall prey to prodigality seem to be the exception - most live decadent lives.

prodigious.great in size, extent: After the relatively small home-run totals in the dead ball era, Babe Ruth's home-run totals were truly prodigious: every year, he set a new all-time record.

profligate.recklessly wasteful: The composer Wagner, while living on a limited salary, was so profligate as to line all the walls of his apartment with pure silk.

profuse.abundant: During mile 20 of the Hawaii marathon, Dwayne was sweating so profusely that he stopped to take off his shirt, and ran the remaining six miles wearing nothing more than skimpy shorts.

profusion.abundance: When Maria reported that she had been visited by Jesus Christ and had proof, a profusion of reporters and journalists descended on the town.

prognostication.prediction: When the senator was asked about where the negotiations would lead, he said that any guess he could make would be an unreliable prognostication.

prolific.productive: Schubert was the most prolific composer, producing hundreds of hours of music before he died at the age of 31.

prolixity.verbosity: I loved my grandfather dearly, but his prolixity would put me to sleep, regardless of the topic.

promulgate.officially make known: The president wanted to promulgate the success of the treaty negotiations, but he had to wait until Congress formally approved the agreement.

propitiate.appease: The two sons, playing their angry father with cheesy neckties for Christmas, were hardly able to propitiate him - the father already had a drawer full of ones he had never worn before or ever planned to.

propitious.favorable: The child's heartbeat is still weak, but I am seeing many propitious signs and I think she may be healing.

proponent.supporter: Ironically, the leading proponent of Flat-Earth Theory flies all over the world in an effort to win more adherents.

prosaic.dull: Unlike the talented artists in his workshop, Paul had no such bent for the visual medium, so when it was time for him to make a stained glass painting, he ended up with a prosaic mosaic.

proscribe.ban: My doctor proscribed my habit of eating donuts with chocolate sauce and hamburger patties for breakfast.

proselytize.attempt to convert: Lisa loves her Mac but says little about it; by contrast, Jake will proselytize, interrogating anyone with an Android about why they didn't purchase an iphone.

protean.versatile: Peter Sellers was truly a protean actor - in Doctor Strangelove he played three very different roles: a jingoist general, a sedate president and a deranged scientist.

provident.planning ahead: In a move that can hardly be described as provident, Bert spent his entire savings on a luxurious cruise, knowing that other bills would come due a couple of months later.

provincial.unsophisticated: Maggie's enthusiasm about her high school team seemed provincial to her college classmates, all of whom were following a nationally ranked team.

provisional.not final: Until the corporate office hands down a definite decision on use of the extra offices, we will share their use in a provisional arrangement.

puerile.childish: Helen enjoyed blowing soap bubbles, but Jim regarded this as puerile, totally unworthy of a woman with Ph.D.

pugnacious.combative: The comedian told one flat joke after another, and when the audience started booing, he pugnaciously spat back at them, 'Hey, you think this is easy - why don't you buffoons give it a shot?'

puissant.powerful: Over the years of service, and quite to his surprise, he became a puissant advisor to the community.

punctilious.overly precise: The colonel was so punctilious about enforcing regulations that men feel compelled to polish even the soles of their shoes.

pundit.expert: Steven Pinker's credentials are unquestioned as a pundit; he has taught at MIT and Stanford, teaches at Harvard, and has published a number of influential books on cognition, language and psychology.

pyrrhic.of a costly victory: George W. Bush's win in the 2000 election was in many ways a pyrrhic victory: the circumstances of his win alienated half of the US population.

quail.draw back in fear: Craig always claimed to be a fearless outdoorsman, but when the thunderstorm engulfed the valley, he quailed at the thought of leaving the safety of his cabin.

qualify.restrict a statement: Chris qualified his love for San Francisco, adding he didn't like the weather there as much as he liked the weather in Los Angeles.

qualm.uneasiness: While he could articulate no clear reason why Harkner's plan would fail, he nevertheless felt qualms about committing any resources to it.

quandary.uncertainty: Steve certainly is in a quandary: if he doesn't call Elaine, she will blame him for everything, but if he does call her, the evidence of where he currently is could cost him his job.

querulous.complaining: The querulous old woman was beginning to wear down even the happier members of the staff with her ceaseless complaining.

quip.witty remark: In one of the most famous quips about classical music, Mark Twain said: Wagner's music is better than it sounds.

quisling.traitor: History looks unfavorably upon quislings; indeed they are accorded about the same fondness as Nero - who watched his city burn down while playing the violin.

quixotic.wildly impractical: For every thousand startups with quixotic plans to be the next big name in e-commerce, only a handful ever become profitable.

quotidian.mundane: Phil gets so involved thinking about Aristotle's arguments that he totally forgets quotidian concerns, such as exercising at eating regularly.

raconteur.storyteller: Jude is entertaining, but he is no raconteur: beyond the handful of amusing stories he has memorized, he has absolutely no spontaneous storytelling ability.

raffish.slightly disreputable: The men found him raffish, but the women adored his smart clothes and casual attitude.

raft.large number: Despite a raft of city ordinances passed by an overzealous council, noise pollution continued unabated in the megalopolis.

raillery.light teasing: The new recruit was not bothered by the raillery, finding most of it light-hearted and good-natured.

rakish.disreputable: As soon as he arrived in the city, the rakish young man bought some drugs and headed straight for the seedy parts of town.

rankle.get under one's skin: His constant whistling would rankle her, sometimes causing her to leave in a huff.

rapprochement.reconciliation: Although Ann hoped that her mother and her aunt would have a rapprochement, each one's bitter accusations against the other made any reconciliation unlikely.

rarefied.refined: Jack's vulgar jokes were not so successful in the rarefied environment of college professors.

rash.reckless: Although Bruce was able to make the delivery in time with a nighttime motorcycle ride in the rain, Susan criticized his actions as rash.

ravenous.very hungry: John didn't eat much at all during the week he had the flu, so now that he is regaining his health, it's not surprising that he has a ravenous appetite.

rebuke.criticize severely: The police chief rebuked the two officers whose irresponsible decisions almost lead to the deaths of seven innocent bystanders.

recapitulation.summary: Every point of the professor's lesson was so clear that the students felt his concluding recapitulation unnecessary.

reconcile.make compatible: Peggy was unable to reconcile her kind friend Jane with the cruel and merciless character Jane played on television.

recondite.arcane: I found Ulysses recondite and never finished the book, waiting instead to read it with someone else so we could penetrate its meaning together.

recrimination.mutual attacks: The two brothers sat and cried, pointing fingers and making elaborate recriminations of the other's guilt.

recrudesce.relapse: After years of gamblers anonymous, Tony thought he'd broken his compulsive slot machine playing, but it took only one trip to the Atlantic City for a full recrudescence - he lost $5000 on the one armed bandit.

redoubtable.inspiring fear: On television basketball players don't look that tall, but when you stand in front of a seven foot tall NBA player, he is truly redoubtable.

redress.correct unfairness: Barry's redress for forgetting his wife's birthday two years in a row was surprising her with a trip to Tahiti.

refractory.stubbornly resistant: Used to studious high school students, Martha was unprepared for the refractory kindergarten kids who neither sat still nor listened to a single word she said.

refute.disprove: No one could refute his theories and propositions, and that is why he was esteemed by all his colleagues in the philosophy department.

relegate.lower in position: When Dexter was unable to fulfill his basic duties, instead of firing him, the boss relegated him to kitchen cleanup.

remiss.be negligent: Remiss in his duty to keep the school functioning efficiently, the principal was relieved of his position after only three months.

remonstrate.forcefully protest: The mothers of the kidnapped victims remonstrated to the rogue government, claiming that the detention violated human rights.

renege.go back on: We will no longer work with that vendor since it has reneged on nearly every agreement.

replete.fully stocked: Only weeks after the hurricane made landfall, the local supermarket shelves were replete with goods, so quick was the disaster relief response.

reprisal.retaliatory action: The Old Testament doctrine of an eye for an eye is not the kind of retaliation practiced in war; rather, an arm, a leg and both ears are the reprisal for the smallest scratch.

reproach.criticize: At first, Sarah was going to yell at the boy, but she didn't want to reproach him for telling the truth about the situation.

reprobate.unprincipled person: These old reprobates drinking all day down by the river - they are not going to amount to much.

repudiate.deny as untrue: Many in the public believed rumors of a UFO crash outside town, so the chief of police did everything he could to repudiate the rumors.

rescind.cancel officially: The man's driver's license was rescinded after his tenth car accident, which meant he would never be allowed to legally drive again.

reservation.doubt: I was initially excited by the idea of a trip to Washington, D.C. but now that I have read about the high crime statistics there, I have some reservations.

resignation.accepting the unpleasant: Since Jack could not think of a convincing reason why he had to miss the seminar, he attended it with a sense of resignation.

resolve.determine: After much thought, Ted resolved not to travel abroad this summer because he didn't have much money in his bank account.

respite.pause from work: Every afternoon, the small company has a respite in which workers play foosball or board games.

restive.restless: The crowd grew restive as the comedian's opening jokes fell flat.

resurgent.rising again: The team sank to fourth place in June, but is now resurgent and about the win the division.

reticent.not talkative: When asked about her father, Helen lost her outward enthusiasm and became rather reticent.

retiring.shy: Nelson was always the first to leave soirees - rather than mill about with 'fashionable' folk, he was retiring, and preferred the solitude of his garret.

retract.take back: Email is wonderfully efficient, but once something awkward or damaging has been sent, there is no way to retract it.

reverent.deeply respectful: The professor could speak objectively about the other composers, but he always lectured about Brahms with a particularly reverent air, unable to offer a single criticism of his compositions.

ribald.comically vulgar: The speaker was famous for his ribald humor, but the high school principal asked him to keep the talk G-rated when he spoke to the student body.

rile.annoy: Dan is usually calm and balanced, but it takes only one intense glare from Sabrina to rile him.

robust.sturdy: Chris preferred bland and mild beers, but Bhavin preferred a beer with more robust flavor.

row.angry dispute: The Prime Minister looked very foolish after his row with the foreign dignitary was caught on video and posted on YouTube.

rudimentary.basic: I would love to be able to present a fully polished proposal to the board, but right now, our plans for the product are still in the most rudimentary stages.

rustic.relating to country: The vacation cabin had no electricity and no indoor plumbing, but despite these inconveniences, Nigel adored its rustic charm.

sagacious.wise: Steve Jobs is surely one of the most sagacious CEOs, making Apple the most recognizable and valuable companies in the world.

sanctimonious.holier-than-thou: Even during the quiet sanctity of the evening prayer, she held her chin high, a sanctimonious sneer forming on her face as she eyed those who were attending church for the first time.

sanction.grant permission: The authorities have sanctioned the use of the wilderness reserve for public use; many expect to see hikers and campers enjoying the park in the coming months.

sangfroid.poise under pressure: The hostage negotiator exhibited a sangfroid that oftentimes was more menacing than the sword at his throat, or the gun at his head.

sanguine.cheerful: With the prospect of having to learn 3000 words during the course of the summer, Paul was anything but sanguine.

sardonic.mocking: A stand-up comedian walks a fine line when making jokes about members of the audience; such fun and joking can quickly become sardonic and cutting.

sartorial.relating to clothes: Monte was astute at navigating the world of finance; sartorially, however, he was found wanting - he typically would attempt to complement his beige tie with a gray suit and white pants.

saturnine.gloomy: Deprived of sunlight, humans become saturnine; that's why in very northernly territories people are encouraged to sit under an extremely powerful lamp, lest they become morose.

savvy.well-informed: Although a great CEO, he did not have the political savvy to win the election.

schadenfreude.joy in other's suffering: From his warm apartment window, Stanley reveled in schadenfreude as he laughed at the figures below, huddled together in the arctic chill.

scintillating.brilliant: Richard Feynman was renowned for his scintillating lectures - the arcana of quantum physics was made lucid as he wrote animatedly on the chalkboard.

screed.abusive rant: Joey had difficulty hanging out with his former best friend Perry, who, during his entire cup of coffee, enumerated all of the government's deficiencies - only to break ranks and launch into some screed against big businesses.

scrupulous.using extreme care: Because of his scrupulous nature, Mary put him in charge of numbering and cataloging the entire collection of rare stamps.

sedulous.diligent: An avid numismatist, Harold sedulously amassed a collection of coins from over 100 countries - an endeavor that took over fifteen years, and to five continents.

self-effacing.modest: The most admirable teachers and respected leaders are those who are self-effacing, directing attention and praise to their students and workers.

semblance.misleading appearance: While the banker maintained a semblance of respectability in public, those who knew him well were familiar with his many crimes.

sententious.moralizing: The old man, casting his nose up in the air at the group of adolescents, intoned sententiously, 'Youth is wasted on the young'.

sentimental.emotional: I don't like romanticism for the same reason I don't like melodramatic acting and soap operas - overly sentimental.

serendipity.luck: By pure serendipity, Sarah discovered, at a flea market in Peoria, a matching earring to replace the one that fell down the storm drain back home.

serene.peaceful: I'd never seen him so serene; usually, he was a knot of stress and anxiety from hours of trading on the stock exchange.

simulacrum.bad imitation: The Shanghai Urban Planning Exhibition Center showcases a simulacrum of all the present and approved buildings in the city of Shanghai.

sinecure.easy job: The position of Research Director is a sinecure: the job entails almost no responsibilities, nor does the person in that position have to answer to anyone.

slapdash.hastily put together: The office building had been constructed in a slapdash manner, so it did not surprise officials when, during a small earthquake, a large crack emerged on the facade of the building.

smattering.small amount: I know only a smattering of German, but Helen is able to read German newspapers and converse with natives.

smug.self-satisfied: When Phil was dating the model, he had a smug attitude that annoyed his buddies.

snide.indirectly mocking: The chairman interpreted Taylor's question about promotions as a snide remark, but in all innocence Taylor was trying to figure out the company's process.

snub.reject bluntly: Wheeler was completely qualified for the committee, but the board snubbed him, choosing an obviously lesser qualified candidate instead.

solecism.social blunder: Mother Anna was always on guard against any solecism from her children and scolded them immediately if any of them talked out of place in public.

solicitous.anxious to please: Our neighbors are constantly knocking on our door to make sure we are okay, and I don't know how to ask them to stop being so solicitous about our health.

solicitude.feeling of concern: I walked to his house in the rain to make sure he had enough to eat while he was sick, but he seemed not to appreciate my solicitude.

soporific.causing sleep: Although the professor is brilliant, his bland monotone gives his lectures a soporific effect.

sordid.morally questionable: The nightly news simply announced that the senator had had an affair, but the tabloid published all the sordid details of the interaction.

spartan.unconcerned with comfort: After losing everything in a fire, Tim decided to live in spartan conditions, sleeping on the floor and owning as little furniture as possible.

specious.misleadingly attractive: Almost every image on TV is specious and not to be trusted.

spendthrift.wasteful with money: Taking weekly trips to Vegas, Megan was a spendthrift whose excesses eventually caught up to her.

splenetic.highly irritable: Ever since the car accident, Frank has been unable to walk without a cane, ans so he has become splenetic and unpleasant to be around.

sporadic.at irregular intervals: The signals were at first sporadic, but we now detected a clear, consistent pattern of electromagnetic radiation emanating from deep space.

spurious.fake: When listening to a politician speak, it is hard to distinguish the spurious claims from the authentic ones.

spurn.reject with contempt: She spurned all his flattery and proposals, and so he walked off embarrassed and sad.

squander.waste: Fearing his money would be squandered by his family, he gave all of it to charity when he died.

squelch.suppress: After the dictator consolidated his power, he took steps to squelch all criticism, often arresting any journalist who said anything that could be interpreted as negative about his regime.

staid.serious, dignified: Frank came from a staid environment, so he was shocked that his college roommate sold narcotics.

stalwart.dependable: Despite all the criticism directed at the president during this scandal, Lisa has remained his stalwart supporter.

start.move suddenly: All alone in the mansion, Henrietta started when she heard a sound.

staunch.dependable: No longer a staunch supporter of Anarchism, Terry now sometimes questions whether society would be better off without defined hierarchies.

steadfast.unwavering: A good captain needs to be steadfast, continuing to hold the wheel and stay the course even during the most violent storm.

stem.limit growth: To stem the tide of applications, the prestigious Ivy requires that each applicant score at least 330 on the Revised GRE.

stipend.regular allowance: He was hoping for a monthly allowance loan from the government, but after no such stipend was forthcoming he realized he would have to seek other means of paying for his college tuition.

stolid.having little emotion: Elephants may appear stolid to casual observers, but they actually have passionate emotional lives.

stringent.strict, harsh: Most of the students disliked the teacher because of his stringent homework policy, but many students would later thank him for demanding so much from them.

stultify.sap enthusiasm: As an undergraduate Mark felt stultified by classes outside his area of study; only in grad school, in which he could focus solely on literary analysis, did he regain scholarly edge.

stymie.hinder: The engineers found their plans stymied at every turn and were ultimately able to make almost no progress on the project.

subsume.contain, include: The rogue wave quickly subsumed the pier and boardwalk, destroying everything in its path.

subterfuge.deceit: Finally deciding to abandon all subterfuge, Arthur revealed to Cindy everything about his secret affair over the past two years.

subversive.opposing authority: The ruling political party has began a campaign to shut down subversive websites that it deems as a threat to national safety.

sullen.brooding: Herbert took board games too seriously, often appearing sullen after losing.

summit.highest point: After hiking for two days, the climbers finally reached the summit of Mount Kilimanjaro.

supercilious.arrogant: Nelly felt the Quiz Bowl director acted superciliously towards the underclassmen; really, she fumed, must he act so preternaturally omniscient each time he intones some obscure fact - as though everybody knows that Mt. Aconcagua is the highest peak in South America.

superfluous.more than necessary: How can we hope to stay open if we don't eliminate all superfluous spending, like catered meetings and free acupuncture Tuesday.

supplant.take the place of: For many, a cell phone has supplanted a traditional phone; in fact, most 20-somethings don't even have a traditional phone anymore.

surfeit.excessive amount: There was no such thing as a surfeit of shopping for Nancy - she could stay at the outlet stores from opening to closing time.

surly.bad-tempered: Every morning, Bhavin was a surly unhappy person, but once he ate breakfast, he became loving, laughing, and a joy to be around.

surreptitious.stealthy: Since his mom was a light sleeper, Timmy had to tiptoe surreptitiously through the entire house, careful to not make the floors creak, until he at last was able to enjoy his plunder: a box of chocolate chip cookies.

sybarite.lover of luxury: Despite the fact that he had maxed out fifteen credit cards, Max was still a sybarite at heart: when the police found him, he was at 1000$ an hour spa in Manhattan, getting a facial treatment.

sycophant.flatterer: The CEO was unaware of the damaging consequences of his choices, largely because he surrounded himself with sycophants who would never dare criticize him.

taciturn.quiet: While the CEO enthusiastically shares his plans and agenda with all who will listen, the CFO is far more taciturn, rarely revealing his perceptive.

tact.proper social behavior: In a tremendous display of tact, Shelly was able to maintain a strong friendship with Marcia, even though Marcia's husband, Frank, confessed to finding Shelly more attractive than Marcia.

tantamount.equal to: In many situations, remaining silent is tantamount to admitting guilt, so speak to prove your innocence.

tarnish.disgrace: Pete Rose was one of the best baseball players of his generation, but his involvement with gambling on baseball games has tarnished his image in the eyes of many.

tawdry.cheap, showy: Carol expected to find New York City magical, the way so many movies had portrayed it, but she was surprised how often tawdry displays took the place of genuine elegance.

taxing.exhausting: The hike to the summit of Mt. Whitney was so taxing that I could barely speak or stand up.

telling.significant: Her unbecoming dress was very telling when it came to her sense of fashion.

telltale.revealing: The many telltale signs of chronic smoking include yellow teeth, and a persistent, hacking cough.

temerity.fearless daring: No child has the temerity to go in the rundown house at the end of the street and see if it is haunted.

temperance.moderation: Welles wasn't known for his temperance - he usually ate enough for two and drank enough for three.

tempered.moderated in effect: The wide-eyed optimism of her youth was now tempered after she had worked many years in the criminal justice system.

tempestuous.intensely emotional: Chuck and Kathy have always been stable and agreeable people on their own, but when they got involved, it was a tempestuous relationship.

tenacious.not giving up: Even the most tenacious advocates for gun ownership must admit some of the dangers that firearms present.

tendentious.biased to view: Because political mudslinging has become a staple of the 24-hour media cycle, most of us, despite protestations to the contrary, are tendentious on many of toady's pressing issues.

tender.offer up formally: The government was loath to tender more money in the fear that it might set off inflation.

thoroughgoing.absolute, complete: As a thoroughgoing bibliophile, one who had turned his house into a veritable library, he shocked his friends when he bought a Kindle.

thrifty.wise with money: He was economical, spending his money thriftily and on items considered essential.

thwart.block: I wanted to spend a week in New York this autumn, but the high costs of travel and lodging thwarted my plans.

timorous.shy: Since this was her first time debating on the stage and before an audience, Di's voice was timorous and quiet for the first 10 minutes.

tirade.angry speech: In terms of political change, a tirade oftentimes does little more than make the person speaking red in the face.

torpor.sluggishness: After work, I was expecting my colleagues to be enthusiastic about the outing, but I found them in a state of complete torpor.

tortuous.winding, twisty: Because the logic behind McMohan's side of the debate was so tortuous, his audience came out either completely confused. or worse, feeling they'd been tricked.

tout.advertise strongly: At the conference, the CEO touted the extraordinary success of his company's Research and Development division.

tractable.easily managed: Compared to middle school students, who have an untamed wildness about them, high school students are somewhat more tractable.

transient.short-lasting: The unpredictable and transient nature of deja vu makes it a very difficult phenomenon to study properly.

transitory.short-lasting: If we lived forever and life was not transitory, do you think we would appreciate life less or more?

transmute.alter in form: One of the goals of alchemy was to find the substance or process that would transmute lead into gold.

travail.hard work: While they experienced nothing but travails in refinishing the kitchen, they completed the master bedroom in less than a weekend.

travesty.mockery: What I expected to be an intelligent, nuanced historical documentary turned out to be a poorly-produced travesty of the form.

treacherous.involving betrayal: Even though Jesse James was an outlaw, his killer, Robert Ford, is remembered more for his treacherous actions than for eliminating a criminal and murderer.

trenchant.incisive: Jill presented a rather superficial treatment of sales in Asia, but her trenchant analysis of sales in Europe inspired a number of insights into how to proceed in that market.

tribulation.suffering: As of 2013, nearly 1.5 million Syrians have fled their country hoping to escape the tribulations of a civil war tearing their country to pieces.

trite.lacking originality: Many style guides recommend not using idioms in writing because these trite expressions are uninteresting and show a lack of imagination on the the part of the writer.

truculence.tendency to fight: When the boss confronted Aaron about his earlier remarks, Aaron responded with utter truculence, simply throwing a glass of water in the boss's face and walking away.

truculent.fierce, savage: Standing in line for six hours, she became increasingly truculent, yelling at DMV employees and elbowing other people waiting in line.

truncate.shorten: The soccer game was truncated when the monsoon rain began to fall.

tumult.chaos, confusion: Riots broke out just in front of our apartment building, and the tumult continued late into the night.

turgid.pompous, tedious: The amount of GRE vocabulary he used increased with his years - by the time he was 60, his novels were so turgid that even his die-hard fans refused to read them.

turpitude.moral wickedness: During his reign, Caligula indulged in unspeakable sexual practices, so it's not surprising that he will forever be remembered for his turpitude.

tyro.beginner: All great writers, athletes, and artists were tyros at one time - unknown, clumsy, and unskilled with much to learn.

umbrage.offense: Since he was so in love with her, he took umbrage at her comments, even though she had only meant to gently tease him.

unassailable.immune to attack: Professor Williams is so self-assured as to seem arrogant, presenting each and every opinion as an unassailable fact.

uncanny.strange, unsettling: Reggie has an uncanny ability to connect with animals: feral cats will readily approach him, and sometimes even wild birds will land on his finger.

uncompromising.inflexible: Bart and Hilda's relationship ultimately failed because they were both so uncompromising that they couldn't agree on an apartment.

unconscionable.unreasonable: The lawyer's demands were so unconscionable that rather than pay an exorbitant sum or submit himself to any other inconveniences, the defendant decided to find a new lawyer.

undermine.weaken: The student undermined the teacher's authority by questioning the teacher's judgment on numerous occasions.

underscore.emphasize: While the hiking instructor agreed that carrying a first aid kit would be a good idea under certain circumstances, he underscored the importance of carrying enough water.

underwrite.support financially: The latest symphony broadcast was made possible with underwriting from the Carnegie Endowment.

unequivocal.having a clear meaning: The President's first statement on the subject was vague and open to competing interpretations, so when he spoke to Congress about the same subject later, he was careful to make his position completely unequivocal.

unflappable.cool under pressure: The house shook and the ground quaked, but my dad was unflappable and comforted the family.

unforthcoming.not cooperative: The teacher demanded to know who broke the window while he was out of the room, but the students understandably were unforthcoming.

unimpeachable.blameless: After his long and unimpeachable service to the company, Sharat felt that a gold watch watch was a slap in the face rather than an honor.

unnerve.make one lose confidence: At one time unnerved by math problems, she began to study avidly, and soon became adept at even permutations and combinations questions.

unprecedented.never done before: When America first created its national parks, the idea of setting aside the most beautiful land in a country was unprecedented in the history of mankind.

unprepossessing.unremarkable: World leaders coming to meet Gandhi would expect a towering sage, and often would be surprised by the unprepossessing little man dressed only in a loincloth and shawl.

unpropitious.unlikely to be successful: With only a bottle of water and a sandwich, the hikers faced an unpropitious task: ascending a huge mountain that took most two days to climb.

unruly.noisy, uncontrollable: Walk in to any preschool and I am sure that you will find an unruly and chaotic scene - unless its nap time.

unscrupulous.unethical: In the courtroom, the lawyer was unscrupulous, using every manner of deceit and manipulation to secure a victory for himself.

unseemly.improper: He acted in an unseemly manner, insulting the hostess and then speaking ill of her deceased husband.

unstinting.very generous: Helen is unstinting with her time, often spending hours at the house of a sick friend.

untenable.indefensible: With the combination of Kepler's brilliant theories and Galileo's telescopic observations, the old geocentric theory became untenable to most of the educated people in Europe.

untoward.inconvenient: Some professors find teaching untoward as having to prepare for lectures and conduct office hours prevents them from focusing on their research.

untrammeled.not limited: The whole notion of living untrammeled inspired the American Revolution and was enshrined in the Declaration of Independence and the Constitution.

unviable.not able to work: The plan was obviously unviable considering it could lead to complete environmental destruction in the river valley.

upbraid.scold harshly: Bob took a risk walking into the Students Barbershop - in the end he had to upbraid the apparently drunk barber for giving him an uneven bowl cut.

urbane.sophisticated: Because of his service as an intelligence officer and his refined tastes, W. Somerset Maugham became the inspiration for the urbane and sophisticate spy James Bond.

vacillate.waver: Some student vacillate between schools when deciding which to attend, while others focus only on one school.

vacuous.lacking intelligence: To the journalist's pointed question, the senator gave a vacuous response, mixing a few of his overall campaign slogans with platitudes and completely avoiding the controversial subject of the question.

vanquish.defeat thoroughly: For years, Argentina would dominate in World Cup qualifying matches, only to be vanquished by one of the European countries during the late stages of the tournament.

vantued.boasted about: For years, Mark talked up his Ping Pong game, yet when he entered the office tournament, his much vaunted skills suddenly failed him and he lost all three games he played.

variance.quality of being different: The cynic quipped, 'There is not much variance in politicians; they all seem to lie'.

vehement.intensely emotional: While the other employees responded to the bad news in a measured way, Andrew responded in a vehement manner, tipping over his desk and shouting at the top of his lungs.

venality.corruption: Even some of the most sacred sporting events are not immune to venality, as many of the officials have received substantial bribes to make biased calls.

veneer.disguising layer: Mark Twain referred to the Victorian Period in America as the Gilded Age, implying the ample moral corruption that lay beneath a mere veneer of respectability.

venerate.respect deeply: The professor, despite his sleep-inducing lectures, was venerated amongst his colleagues, publishing more papers yearly than all of his peers combined.

venial.pardonable: His traffic violations ran the gamut from the venial to egregious - on one occasion he simply did not come to a complete stop; another time he tried to escape across state lines at speeds in excess of 14-mph.

veracious.truthful: While we elect our leaders in the hope that every word they speak will be veracious, history has shown that such a hope is naive.

verisimilitude.appearance of truth: All bad novels are bad for numerous reasons; all good novels are good for their verisimilitude of reality, placing the readers in a world that resembles the one they know.

veritable.without a doubt: Frank is a veritable life-saver - last year, on two different occasions, he revived people using CPR.

vicarious.not lived directly: The advent of twitter is a celebrity stalker's dream, as he or she can - through hundreds of intimate tweets - vicariously live the life of a famous person.

vicissitude.change in fortune: Even great rulers have their vicissitudes - massive kingdoms have diminished overnight, and once beloved kings have faced the scorn of angry masses.

vie.compete for: While the other teams in the division actively vie for the championship, this team seems content simply to go through the motions of playing.

vilify.speak ill of: Todd was noble after the divorce, choosing to say only complimentary things about Barbara, but Barbara did not hesitate to vilify Todd.

vindicate.clear of blame: Even seven Tour de France wins cannot vindicate Lance Armstrong in the eyes of the public - that the athlete used performance enhancing drugs invalidates all those wins.

vindictive.seeking revenge: Though the other girl had only lightly poked fun of Vanessa's choice in attire, Vanessa was so vindictive that she waited for an entire semester to get the perfect revenge.

virago.screaming woman: Poor Billy was the victim of the virago's invective - she railed at him for a good 30 minutes about how he is the scum of the earth for speaking loudly on his cellphone in public.

vitriol.abusive language: His vitriol spewed forth from a deep seated racism that consumed his whole life.

vitriolic.harsh in tone: While the teacher was more moderate in her criticism of the other student's paper, she was vitriolic toward Peter's paper, casting every flaw in the harshest light.

vituperate.scold harshly: Jason had dealt with disciplinarians before, but nothing prepared him for the first week of boot camp, as drill sergeants vituperated him for petty oversights such as forgetting to double knot the laces on his boots.

vociferous.offensively loud: In giving Marcia a particular vociferous response, Paul caused people at every other table in the restaurant to turn around and look at them angrily.

volubility.talkativeness: The professor's volubility knows no bounds; he could talk through a hurricane and elaborate a point from one St. Patrick's Day to the next.

voracious.very hungry: Steven was a voracious reader, sometimes finishing two novels in the same day.

wanting.lacking: She did not think her vocabulary was wanting, yet there were so many words that inevitably she found a few she didn't know.

wanton.showing no limits: Due to wanton behavior and crude language, the drunk man was thrown out of the bar and asked to never return.

wax.increase gradually: Her enthusiasm for the diva's new album only waxed with each song; by the end of the album, it was her favorite CD yet.

whimsical.driven by impulse: Adults look to kids and envy their whimsical nature at times, wishing that they could act without reason and play without limitation.

winsome.charming: She was winsome by nature, and many people were drawn to this free and playful spirit.

zeitgeist.spirit of the times: Each decade has its own zeitgeist - the 1990's was a prosperous time in which the promise of the American Dream never seemed more palpable.

zenith.highest point: At the zenith of his artistic career, Elvis was outselling any other artist on the charts.
